review_content:
A beige aesthetic sandalmusk polished with plastic-toned saffron. I have a type and that type is fake wood!! As a Santal 33 Big Bottle owner, I love this genre. This is the scent of a Lincoln log McMansion, more plywood and laminate than actual tree. It’s sweet, it’s clean, it’s got central heating. Takes me back to the B&BW “Sensual Amber” line of the 2000s (be still my heart). Feels like the sawdust static counterpart to the white noise of Fugazzi’s Angel Dust. Unfortunately didn’t last more than two hours on my skin, but I will go out of my way to spritz whenever I pass through Sephora.

Mental Snapshot: It’s 2005. You’re at your friend’s Tuscan-style house in the bougie subdivision. (They have an island in their kitchen!). Everything’s mahogany, granite, and wrought iron. And a whole lot of biscuit, buff, and beige. They have a home theatre. You sink into a brown pleather sectional. It smells like this.

tl;dr: model home musk

review_title: Creamy and spicy saffron with pencil shavings
review_content:
Didn’t take a look at the Parfumo page before trying out this fragrance, so I’m happy to see people have immediately picked on the similarities between this one an Memo Paris’ fragrance.

The first 15 minutes are very similar to Cappadocia. It has the same leathery-like saffron with creamy and slightly sweet facets. It’s spicy and just so comforting. I barely get any of the other notes although I do detect a freshness and something less opaque and thick than Memo Paris’ version. Things start to take a different turn when Phlur’s version starts to smell like saffron accompanied by pencil shavings. Sandalwood and cedarwood in the base might have contributed to this. Phlur’s version is also more palatable to those who want something non-obtrusive and wearable. It’s also softer and doesn’t have monstrous projection, which makes it more versatile than Memo Paris’s version. I’d say this one is a lovely, cheaper alternative to its niche version, but since I already have a full bottle of Cappadocia (that I love very much), this one won’t be making it to my collection.

This feels exceptionally 70s; reminds me of a Sauna from my birthplace of Finland that was built then, and you're using it Now. It feels like a station wagon with wood grain in the doors and the console, or perhaps a cabin with a conversation pit and one of those weird circular fireplaces. At no point do you get any sort of natural wood, before it had been processed in some way.

review_title: Wood - now in the leading role
review_content:
Föst Impreschn: The whimsical name doesn’t reveal that this fragrance immediately comes across as s e r i o u s - understated, yet not shy, stylish, but present.
Fun Fact: This is the first perfume with wood in the leading role that I genuinely like from top to bottom.
Sorry: Liking "wood perfume" is so new to me that I’m waiting to rate it until my generously filled sample vial - thanks, @Lutz89 - is all gone.

Background: If you catch a whiff of synthetic here, you probably haven't smelled the truly penetrating scent of freshly cut (various!) woods very often… So. I tend to stick my nose right at the cutting edge whenever I come across usable wood out and about ^^. Some tree cuts smell like something out of an eight-year-old's chemistry set, an eight-year-old who tried to create a wood scent with the strangest ingredients -
Then again, you might smell d e c e n t wood scents, or very sweet, barely noticeable aged ones, sometimes strongly resinous, and: As a crowning achievement, I once found a pure (!) vanilla scent. Without resin and - without wood XD
Since then, I can better understand that vanilla aromas can also be derived from wood - well, anyway!

Scent: As if a supporting character could shine in a leading role ^^
You can actually smell a clean, straightforward mix of various wood scents here, which you might recognize from the great outdoors as described… It overall feels dry, “welcomingly warm,” I would say, instilling trust. (Oh yes, and - Ganymede is somewhat similar to a linden tree from a flying saucer.)
Who: I actually see the scent primarily on male school principals - purely associatively - and on older female-presenting individuals in situations where they want to come across as discreet yet noticeable, serious yet exuding calm and friendliness.
When: Personally, I can’t imagine wearing this scent at any other time than in the autumn months. Except now for testing. Hehe.

Pyramid: I was baffled that there are supposed to be “only” two wood scent directions represented, then I was surprised by lemon and saffron, and I still wonder - What The Geier, cyclamen flowers really smell like n o t h i n g at all - - - - Well, anyway.

Bottle: Let’s keep silent about that

H/S/Animal Ethics: My surprise upon googling to find out that the manufacturers not only created something truly wonderful but also work consistently cruelty-free without any greenwashing was enormous. - I allow myself to quote from the Phlur homepage:

“Yes, Phlur is cruelty-free. They don't test their finished products or ingredients on animals, and neither do their suppliers or any third-parties. It's also verified that their products are not tested on animals anywhere in the world, including mainland China.”

With “Verified Cruelty Free,” there are often more discreet H/S, which are absolutely true here: Sprayed at 4 PM, still a close-to-skin hint detectable at 9 AM.
Nice! - Consequently, I can’t confirm a longevity of 6.5. Regarding sillage:
In contrast to my beautiful but really weak Sticky Popcorn, this is even a two-spray scent. (Unless, of course, someone needs huge clouds to mark their territory. For me personally, a cheeky little cloud is always enough.)

Update: Surroundings confirm - the scent is detectable for hours with two sprays, hehe, even elicited cute MMMMHs XD

review_title: One of my new favorite fragrances!
review_content:
“Somebody Wood” by Phlur is a very pleasant, warm perfume that immediately gave me a sense of comfort when I first smelled it. The main notes of sandalwood and cedarwood come out very well on my skin and provide a gentle and soothing woody note.

The fragrance starts with citrusy top notes that blend nicely with the warm wood notes. In the heart of the perfume, there are subtle spice notes that add an extra depth to the scent without overwhelming it.

Over time, “Somebody Wood” develops into a persistently warm and inviting fragrance that is great for all-day wear. Overall, it’s a fantastic choice for anyone looking for a warm and sensual unisex scent.

This is such a good vanilla buttercream. It is sweet, vanilla heaven. A gourmand dream. I absolutely love this one. It is buttery and rich with sugary frosting. It isn't sickeningly sweet (just know sickeningly sweet to me does not exist- I am a sickeningly sweet fiend. You cannot give me a fragrance that is too sweet or at least, I haven't found one yet.) The longevity is decent for a FFM, and the sillage is average as well. I wish they had this in a full size. Right now, I just have two mini ones. This is a great heading to bed fragrance as well. It's very comforting. You can fall asleep to frosting and wake up and apply something new with no issues. This was a great blind buy.

If you're looking for a good "basic gourmand vanilla", this is it! So many good vanillas from BBW/VS have other notes that are dominant, like:

- bourbon ( Wild Madagascar Vanilla EAU DE PARFUM )
- cake ( Confetti Cake Pop )
- cookies (the 2022 version of Happy Birthday )
- incense ( Vanilla Lace FRAGRANCE MIST )
- marshmallow ( Vanilla Bean Noel )
- "metallic" ( Wrapped in Vanilla )
- musk ( Bare Vanilla )
- "playdoh" ( Warm Vanilla Sugar FRAGRANCE MIST )
- powder ( "Fresh Vanilla | Bath & Body Works" )
- sandalwood ( Vanilla Noir )
- "woods" ( Wicked Vanilla Woods )

Don't get me wrong, I still love plenty of the above. But Vanilla Buttercream doesn't have other notes that dominate, and sometimes that's all you need.

It's an uncomplicated, true vanilla buttercream; rich vanilla, sweetened with a touch of caramel (which just feels like a warmer version of the butter in buttercream).

I wish it projected more, it's fairly soft - but I'm still happy with it, and am impressed with the longevity for it being a "fluffy vanilla" profile (lasts several hours on my skin). This will be my go-to for birthdays!

review_title: I did it, I found it!
review_content:
It was an exploratory journey that was ultimately very worthwhile.
Dozens of fresh summer scents arrived in the form of samples at my house, I almost felt sorry for the postman.
From the moment I first experienced LV afternoon swim last year, I was on the hunt for a perfume that would do justice to that incredibly good note while still having good longevity. Let’s be honest, all fresh citrus scents fade quickly, it’s in their nature. Sure, the heart and base notes might last all day, but that’s not what makes the fragrances special.

On my discovery journey, I sniffed out many great summer scents and slowly came to terms with the fact that I would never find a "better LV AS." I was just about to order Pomelo Sorrento by Gritti (also a great scent), but then I discovered the house of Pana Dora and I am so happy that it happened.

Forever Love is very close to afternoon swim in the top note, to be honest, it still doesn’t manage to offer that incredible zest and freshness that I only know from LV, but it provides more depth and an interesting opening. The citrus notes seem to last twice as long (about 2 hours), but what fundamentally distinguishes the two are the heart and base notes.
One thing I liked less about afternoon swim was the drydown, which for my taste had a somewhat unpleasant synthetic quality, and that’s where Forever Love excels. Even though it is still slightly citrusy, the heart note is a different caliber, a wonderfully warm floral scent that stands on its own and brings joy for hours.

In short, I have finally found my perfect scent for hot summer days, now I just have to wait a long time until I can enjoy it in appropriate weather.

For anyone who loves afternoon swim like I do but expects more for their money, Forever Love is a must-try!

review_title: Direction Afternoon Swim, convinces me more
review_content:
Just in time for the start of summer, this fantastic summer scent has arrived for me. I've had my eye on this fragrance for a while, but at the full price of €245, it was too expensive for me. In shops that often have discounts, this one was usually sold out. Now I struck at a slight discount, which is still a hefty price. But high-quality summer fragrances should be worth it, especially when it comes to scents for the intense (and humid) heat.
This is my first Pana Dora that I have purchased and tested. I have found a few exciting fragrances in their small range that I will definitely test as well. I will still see if this hype in the community is justified. They definitely seem to be well-received in general. With Sweden, this brand has an exotic country for perfume. Behind this brand is the Syrian immigrant and perfumer Ibrahim Al-Zorbi. He seems to have talent, judging by the reviews, especially for the releases from 2023-2024. It’s worth checking out, especially if you are looking for mass-appeal niche fragrances and like to go with the hype.

I came across this scent because I was looking for an alternative to "Afternoon Swim | Louis Vuitton." For me, it has one of the best top notes when it comes to the intense heat and that carefree midsummer feeling. Disadvantage: It absolutely does not last, costs €280, and is only available at LV without any discounts/offers. If you can find it used at a significantly lower price, that would be an alternative. However, I decided on this Forever Love.
The name Forever Love is, of course, beautifully chosen. The fragrance comes in a lovely round orange box. The highlight is, of course, the bottle with the moose head. It should not be confused with the Penhaligon's Portrait series, which has a similar cap. A bottle from this brand visually enhances the collection. Extremely elegantly crafted, especially the cap. The sprayer is also top-notch and dispenses the perfect amount and is buttery smooth. For that, a clear 10/10.
In terms of scent, you definitely get a great alternative to Afternoon Swim, especially in the top note. Full-on good mood through citrusy, juicy, and summery notes. Afternoon Swim might have a bit more of that swimming pool vibe, but this Forever Love does not need to hide. It is thoroughly likable and will not find many enemies. Lemon, orange, mandarin, and bitter grapefruit. You get this in the opening. Citrusy-fruity-juicy and just straight-up good mood. In the heart note, several fruits come through, which is rather rare in the heart note. After 1 hour, it becomes very juicy and soft. Mango and melon, along with a bit of spicy, delicate ginger and some gentle geranium. Delicate flowers also come through, which submit to the citrusy and fruity DNA. In the third part of the fragrance and also during the dry down, woods and sweetness emerge; the fresh notes last about 4-5 hours, which is absolutely great for such freshies.
The longevity is significantly better than the LV. I think the fragrance should last about 8 hours or longer, with the first 2-3 hours performing really well with this fantastic freshness. Overall, this fragrance is worth it when it comes to a good midsummer scent.

Overall, a fantastic citrusy-fruity-juicy fragrance with a woody base. A great alternative for the upcoming summer. Not an Afternoon Swim clone, but a great alternative to it.

review_title: Absolute top perfume from Pana Dora!
review_content:
What can I say?
If this isn't a summer scent, then I don't know what is..

Actually, I prefer perfumes that lean more towards the woody/spicy/leathery direction (e.g. Tom Ford / Sauvage, etc.).
Basically, perfumes for the colder seasons.

So, as it goes, my wife and I set out to find a fresher, fruitier summer scent.
In a niche perfumery, we expressed our preferences and sought advice.
After some time, we both stumbled upon this perfume.

At first, you encounter the sweet note of the perfume, particularly the orange/lavender component is noticeable. After testing it on my skin and a few minutes later, the citrus note emerges and brings a refreshing feeling with it.

Absolute recommendation for spring and summer! This perfume is neither too citrusy (Malibu - Party in the Bay), nor too sweet (Pana Dora - Aqua de Dora) - the oriental note from the manufacturer is still faintly detectable without overwhelming anyone.
Honestly, my wife loves it and I am also thrilled by it (strangely, it's the first time we both like a perfume so much).

From my perspective, three sprays (left and right side of the neck and at the back) are enough, and the scent lasts 7-8 hours. The sillage is fantastic; you can still smell it from a distance of 4-5 meters without it coming off as intrusive.

Overall:

Scent note: fruity, soft, citrusy, slightly oriental mixture.
Longevity: 3 sprays -> 7-8 hours

For me, it's a scent that can be worn at any time of day during the summer in warm temperatures; a slightly seductive note cannot be denied.

Absolute purchase recommendation from the niche house of Pana Dora!

Sour and bitter citrus scent. Directly on the skin, it reminds me of Nio; in the air, it smells more floral and fruity. I can mostly smell lemon and melon with a hint of floral notes. It smells very natural, not a trace of synthetics. Sillage and longevity are good for a fresh scent, definitely better than with Nio. I like it very much, it's something different.

I was looking for a really great summer scent in the store and then I came across the Pana Dora Forever Love and it immediately captivated me. I tried it on my skin and on the tester and it was just wow, it felt like someone was throwing a bowl of fruits in my face. It was also as if I were on a tropical island where I was on vacation, it's 30 degrees and up and I'm eating...

Beautiful, light scent for summer or sports. Pleasantly citrusy, airy start with a certain delicious sweetness in the background. I find it very mass-appealing and people-pleasing, definitely a compliment-getter without being too noticeable or off-putting. It slightly reminds me of Sedley by Parfums de Marly. The longevity for me was over 6 hours.

It is a beautiful scent that strongly reminds me of a watermelon. The longevity is not the best so far, but it's not really bad either. On clothes, the scent lasts easily for a day, but on the skin, I can no longer perceive it after a few hours.
For the retail price, I probably wouldn't buy this scent, but if you catch a good deal, it's definitely worth it!

The scent is very beautiful, a fruit explosion describes it perfectly. Unfortunately, the longevity and sillage are a bit lacking, which is normal for a summer fragrance. Personally, I find it sometimes a bit too feminine, but in the height of summer, it’s still my go-to along with Mahina from Parfums Delmar. Therefore, I still give a real recommendation as the fragrance DNA...

At first reminiscent of Afternoon Swim, as a zesty citrus combination of oranges and mandarins manifests, this fragrance transforms into a fresh fruit scent with a slight floral touch. I associate it with juicy fruits and bright flowers. The bottle is typically Pana Dora, an absolute eye-catcher, very high-quality and simply beautiful. Compliments are definitely received...

review_title: shortly in love, then sugar shock
review_content: A spicy start, red berries, a lot of cotton candy vibe. This definitely has something and instantly lifts the mood. However, on my skin, it quickly shifts into a very sweet, almost childish direction. The scent strongly reminds me of one of the earlier Cherry fragrances by Escada. This slightly buoyant, candy-like fruitiness is very present here. As it develops, it becomes...

review_title: Forever Love - Beautiful, but not a love for eternity
review_content: Forever Love is one of those fragrances that is highly rated in the community - perhaps my expectations were a bit too high because of that. Unfortunately, it has personally disappointed me a little. Right after spraying, I am greeted by a slightly soapy note that, while clean and well-groomed, feels a bit too tame and inconspicuous for my taste. The composition is undoubtedly...

Forever Love - a fragrance I bought for summer last year. At first, I had some difficulties with the scent, as I am not a fan of the note of ginger. However, it is quite present in the fragrance. Nevertheless, the ginger, combined with the floral and fruity notes, is executed so incredibly well and unusually that I have come to love this scent. This fragrance typically...

A wonderful freshie with great fruit accords. The scent starts incredibly fruity and full of orange/lemon with fantastic citrus notes. Immediately, the ginger and mango note become noticeable. In the drydown, it retains this fruity note and becomes pleasantly sweet. The citrus notes gradually weaken in the drydown. For me, the best summer fragrance ever.

As an eau de cologne, or so it's stated, (I have a belief that it may have received this concentration based on gendered norms) it does falter after a while in longevity. However, I test all of my fragrances in the overbearing Louisiana heat and humidity, so to continue to smell this fragrance currently, even as it hovers closer to the skin is a testament to it strength. With the notes provided, I can assume the spiciness must be derived from the 'Sequoia' note. Rosemary may provide more of the spice as well.
It is a pleasant 'red' fragrance, not necessarily essential, but it is a good pick up if you're inclined to spicy, woody fragrances. Fortunately for me, it also has enough freshness in it to pull off on a late spring day as this one. I would rather wear this one on the eve of autumn and spring, but in Louisiana, you can wear it in the winter. Avoid in August and September.

review_title: Plenty of better options for your weekend!
review_content:
Crisp green-fruity-citrus scent with no praise or blame – well, more blame than praise, quite on the synthetic/acrid side (a floor detergent, basically – imagine you’re using it to clean the tropical juice you’ve just spilled on the floor, here’s Weekend). Quite cheap overall, especially for the first minutes which are fairly loud and pungent; once it settles a bit on skin and finds its proper tuning, it’s a mildly enjoyable and exceedingly generic green-citrus-musky scent with those annoying metallic-pungent nonsense nuances many brands try to pass as “tropical fruity notes” – although luckily it’s more green-woody and citrus than tropical. Not that acrid anymore if compared to the opening, more metallic and “gassy” after a couple of hours, but still miles away from being something pleasant to wear. Anyway, linearly green and fruity on the lime-tropical side, and that’s all. Personally I’d rate this mediocre, to be generous; but if you’re looking for a summer fragrance and your pretenses are really (really, really) low, then here you go.

5/10

review_title: Weekend is so uplifting and sunny
review_content:
This is my all-time favorite scent. Make a list and it is a number 1.

Here's why. I personally buy perfume based on my feelings, not on the scent or how they perform.

When I was young, like very very young, my friend's brother used this one. He is very handsome but his style is free-spirited and fearless/carefree personality.

I adored him so much and this Burberry weekend and D&G Light Blue are always on his vanity. I saw him spraying one or two before going out. He is always smelling so good, and this is the first scent that made me into the world of fragrance.

Every time I wear this, it always brings back to my childhood. A good memory. A loving past.

How many weekend bottles I used? 7 and I still have two 100ml as a backup.

I love Citrusy fragrance so this is the number one, all the time. I don't care about whether the weather is hot or cold. But however, I might have 20 bottles to wear based on the occasions, but if it is the weekend, this is one, there is no other.

It's no secret that my favourite perfume of all time is Weekend for Women, so I was eager to see what the male version was like with the intention of perhaps purchasing it for my significant other.

This cologne is not a floral like its female equivalent, which I consider a good thing, (I like my men to smell masculine). Weekend for men is quite fruity yet pleasantly sour, that makes this scent a fantastic Summer fragrance, as it is sharp and refreshing without being too overpowering.

The lasting strength is not bad, however I'm speaking from a female perspective where many of our fragrances are eau de parfum rather than eau de toilette, so the lasting power might actually be fantastic for some.

Weekend is so light and clean that it could actually be worn by a very daring woman. However, I do believe that this fragrance is very masculine. The only element of this fragrance that mirrors Weekend for Women is the honey note in the drydown, which adds warmth and a little bit of sweetness.

My verdict on this fragrance; I love it yet I don't think this type of fragrance would suit my man, (he's more into dark and woodsy scents). However, I will consider buying this for some of my male friends when it comes time to buy them gifts.

It is a nice Fresh Citrusy fragrance, A Unique perfume for Hot weather. This is a bit mature and synthetic but it smells so good with reasonable price. It opens up with sweet fresh citrusy combo and green notes in the background then dry down is sweet musky woody. The Ivy note is dominant in this scent, Longevity is good.
Rating : 7 / 10

At first I was pretty "meh" about Weekend. I got it for $20 on a whim, and wasn't too impressed after wearing it a couple times. Floral mixed with honey, not my taste at the time.

Fast forward a couple years when I'm going through all my old scents during the summer, and I give it a shot. What was once floral-honey has transformed into freshly cut grass, with a good dose of sweet honey and a hint of citrus peel.

Suddenly this fragrance makes complete sense, and paints a beautiful portrait of a leisurely Saturday during the summer- cutting grass, drinking sweet tea, and eating fruit fresh off the tree.

I wonder how this fragrance would do with a base of Tobacco to complete this picture, however as it is Weekend is a great, low key scent for when you need a pick-me-up or want to smell good while working out on the yard.

This is the weekend of a man who is part of a couple, I'd say. There's a whiff of coffee from breakfast still hanging in the air, but now he's out in the garden mowing the lawn while she is quickly wiping down the house (the cleaning agent being Citrus Fresh). Later on he goes fishing: I smell an aquatic note that reminds me of fish fresh from the water. After that, the...

Ive never felt so strongly about mediocrity. Burberry Weekend is the definition of 5/10, just eh, completely inoffensive, pleasant yet utterly univocative. It smells like a freshly ironed white button shirt. On days I dont want to think about what I spray on and I don't want it to last long so that I can choose something better later then I will choose this. To bridge a...

“Weekend For Men” is 24 (!) years old… Wow. You wouldn’t think so. And it is the first real hit from my big order of cheapies from last week that will probably stay beloved in my collection forever. And it might now even be my favorite Burberry scent. Much too overlooked, far too little written about. That has to change! Or maybe not. It can just stay mine. But it is a...

...grapefruit are in my nose during a walk in southern Europe. But there is also the aroma of ivy, moss, and something woody in the air. It’s simply beautiful. When applying this fragrance, you first get lemons, grapefruit, and mandarin. The green of ivy joins in, along with a mossy note and a hint of woodiness. To give this perfume something special, it is sweetened...

In my opinion this is one of the best and most interesting L'Occitane fragrance I've tried so far. It's quite unique and I can't think of many perfumes that come close to its smell or style.

Eau d'Iparie is mysterious, spiritual and profound. The myrrh and incense confer a vaguely sacred aura that reminds of religion, churches, saints and the meaning of the divine adoration and yet, this perfume has a markedly dark character, a solemnity that may hide secrets and perhaps occult knowledge. At the borderline between grace and obscurity, this scent gives me quite a spiritual trip.

I think Eau d'Iparie is best suited for cold winter days, late autumn trips to old villages in France, Catholic sermons and why not, funerals. It's thoroughly well done and can really put you in a mystical mood, if you know how to wear it.

~ I am considering placing a one hundred dollar bid on an e-bay half bottle based purely on initial impressions of this L'Occitane it is that good! I was fortunate enough to receive a sample of this as an added bonus from a generous perfumista and I soo thank her! This is a beautiful myrrh the type that you want to be surrounded in and keep it for yourself. To me it is also a very sheer airy dried herbal scent like a breeze in a grassy meadow. I don't know whether the subtle incense actually applies to the skin or just hovers and dances around it like a free spirit? Although not listed I also get a hint of a dried aged rose. The kind that you would keep pressed in your favorite heavy book as a sentimental reminder of a past lover. Is this unisex to my nose perhaps? But it doesn't matter to this man I want what's in this! I may not be able to hold it like a precious memory but just to contain it for a little while in a bottle on my shelf is all I can hope for. ~
Kind Regards, Plat ~

My rewiew refers to the Eau d'Iparie I remember, I mean the vintage version.
It was opulent, rich, resinous and similar to a sacred perfume. A real masterpiece in a particular refined bottle at a price quite affordable . Nowadays I don't recognize the modern version , in a totally different packaging and with a price too high in comparison to the product lighter than than the vintage version. If you love the original perfume and you find an old bottle, buy it immediately!

Amazing stuff in its first release. It is so interesting, smoky, herbal, dark and special. Not for everybody, if you love extra sweet candy girly perfumes, this isn't for you. This one needs to be considered definitely as a unisex. It is great for layering too. After finding myself testing it once and again, I bought it for winter sunny days.

Another one to share with my companion.

This morning I stumbled upon CocoLeFay's comment about Eau d`Iparie, and since I have the fragrance sitting in the farthest corner of my collection, I was a bit surprised that she perceives it as delicate. So I tested it again right away. I noticed that while my version is indeed the same bottle, it lacks the obviously embossed smooth area for the label. However, it clearly reads "Eau d`Iparie" on the bottom of my bottle. I bought it a long time ago at a L`Occitane outlet in a pharmacy.

On my skin, a dry spicy-resinous note emerges immediately, which - and this is the crux of the matter - can truly be a revelation for myrrh and incense lovers when applied very sparingly. For everyone else, it’s probably sheer horror.

Even though the listed pyramids are not always really complete. Here, it seems that there is really nothing more to it. Therefore, the fragrance comes across as quite one-dimensional to me. I like both nuances, but I lack a bit of imagination; it is for me only intense, but rather flat and blatant. It almost feels like I only have a base note of a once dark, spicy chypre, which is still quite loud. This is not unpleasant, but as I said, somewhat meager.

It’s no coincidence that I mentioned above that I applied Eau l`Iparie in the morning, because even now, about 11 hours later, it is still mercilessly noticeable on the back of my hand. Unfortunately, it does not fit the spring at all, but I have to endure it now.

This fragrance awakens my experimental spirit, and I will layer it with a dark rose or something green; who knows, maybe I will have an aha moment then. I can very well imagine that. Otherwise, it just needs a bit of gold, and the Three Wise Men have their gifts for the journey to Bethlehem. What is a baby supposed to do with that??

review_title: As harmless as the songs of Sunrise Avenue..
review_content: ...the sun doesn’t exactly rise with it either. I haven't known Occitane for very long..I love Eau des Baux, I really like Ambre..even though it could use a bit more edge. I expected exactly this from iparie...pepper, incense, myrrh..I was actually expecting something between Baux and Ambre. Unfortunately, the result is a bit more feminine and softer than...

Normally, it takes me a long time, sometimes several attempts, to know if I like a fragrance. It was a rainy shopping day with my dear sister. We were browsing in the L'Occitane shop since I like to pop in there. I actually wanted to take my beloved Amber with me, but the lady said, "No, unfortunately, it's no longer available." "Damn," I thought. However, she immediately...

L'Occitane Eau d'Ìpartie is said to be a perfume that contains myrrh and frankincense. At first, I thought the perfume might be too strong or even heavy for me, as these two ingredients are known to often have a strong scent! But no, here both notes present themselves as soft, almost a bit velvety, not very smoky, but pleasantly fragrant. The perfume starts very quietly,...

No, Eau d'Iparie and I will not become friends. After the retro bottle caught my attention positively (it reminds me of the bottles I admired as a little girl in my grandma's bathroom cabinet) and since I am generally a big fan of Occitance, I decided to spray it on after a first sniff at the bottle. A mistake, as it turned out. A big one, in fact. It has practically never...
...a delicate fragrance that is definitely suitable for everyday wear.

review_title: Buttery Cappuccino with a Cherry on Top
review_content: Eccentricity is the perfect name for this, but Indulgence would have fit just as well. Because what could be more indulgent than a rich, steamy cappucino that meets head-to-head with a cherry amaretto, and Plop! gets a piece of butter taking a dive in the hot, hot liquid? Surprisingly, it's only sweet for just five minutes, when the caramel is featured in the opening. Then it starts to sober down, but damn! you can feel those calories building up as that butter starts to coat everything. Yet another, superior version of Coffee Addict, if you like to explore the scent of brewed coffee.

New Fragrance by Hollister. Wrapping surely is a matter of taste, however I like the cubical flask decorated with a removable Surfer Figure. This Hollister Fragrance is different from all others because it seems to be quite maritime and leads to associations of ocean and breakers and thereby to good mood (works at least for me). Dosed to strong, the top notes might appear a little to penetrative, maybe because of the sage. Lasts at least medium if not long and gives a maritime freshness. I have heard a lot of people drawing comparisons to "Fierce" of Abercrombie & Fitch, which I cannot really follow...

Yes, the Beach Boys once sang this song and this fragrance fits perfectly with it.

A warm summer day, a fine sandy beach, crashing waves, hot chicks, and the hair is on point. All that's missing is the perfect scent for such a hot day. Apply sunscreen and then Break Line. There’s no better feeling than that. Grab the surfboard and off we go into the waves.

As for the scent, it starts off very fresh and sweet, but with too high a dosage, it can become a bit piercing. Then it becomes quite maritime, but warm, not cold. That’s probably the warm sand. There’s also a wooden note added. For me, the fragrance notes fit perfectly with the bottle and the name.

The sillage and longevity are in the average range, but quite good for an EdC. As for the bottle, it is indeed special. The EdC comes in a cubic bottle topped with a surfer statue. However, that doesn’t necessarily have to be there.

For me, Break Line is the better SoCal and lasts much longer. Maybe this should be used in stores this time, because I can’t stand SoCal anymore.

I don’t understand the comparison with "Fierce," because if that were the case, they would probably have chosen "Break Line" instead of SoCal.

Recently in Raleigh, NC: Sprayed Fierce on my right hand in the Abercrombie store, walked two stores further and sprayed Break-Line on my left hand.

It was good that I remembered which scent went on which hand, as it became hardly distinguishable afterwards. Break Line smells a bit more citrusy, which limits the differences. No, wait, that's not true, Fierce was still there in the evening, whereas Break Line was no longer detectable by the afternoon. Then again, it only costs half...

great new scent from Hollister that stands out from the other fragrances of the fashion chain. I find it fresh, masculine, and just awesome!!! Unique bottle with a surfer statue!!! It's worth trying this fragrance, you will be pleasantly surprised!!! And be careful with the dosage, less is more in this case too!!

It didn’t win me over. It kind of reminds me of Lamar (I like it, sometimes.., though) , but in a thicker, more synthetic-feeling version. It hits you right away with a blast of ripe fruits and heavy florals. What throws it off for me is the sweet, sugary amber base — it just feels a bit much.

It’s definitely rich, intense, and super long-lasting, but overall kind of chaotic. If you’re into bold, fruity-gourmand scents that wrap around you like a cloud, this might be your thing — just not mine.

review_title: Imagine rose, caramel, and spice wrapped in confidence — that’s Can’t Get Enough.
review_content:
It is indulgent, full-bodied, confident. The star here is rose, shaken with pink pepper. I get the Caramel sweetness right away too, the same intensity as rose.

Please don't be fooled by comparisons to Delina Exclusif , Atomic Rose EAU DE PARFUM and especially Impadia - they aren't alike at all! Atomic rose is a dewy and fresh rose, Impadia is rose and orange blossom. All they share is a rose note, and even then, different roses.

At the heart we have the molecule hedione, the kind of thing that gives florals a haunting, addictive feel. I'm a big fan of how Initio use perfumery ingredients in their blends, and this release wasn't an exception. Hedione is a molecule that triggers the pleasure center of the brain. It has a pheromone-like quality. And here Initio may have tricked you into liking their perfumes. Using science ;) In the dry down we are met with vanilla - plush, decadent and warm.

If I were to sum it up: it feels like a bold rose gourmand scent, that’s not too sweet and not too floral. I value fragrance that moves you, that tells a story, that doesn’t simply hide in the background. And Can't Get Enough isn't the quiet type - it announces itself.

If you’re into niche and you’ve loved other Initio drops, or you’re just ready for something that feels indulgent and well-done, this will sit well with you. A perfect scent for fall and winter.

I do not get the notes as listed. Fresh, this has a tart plummy smell. There’s an intriguing creaminess as well that prompted me to skin test. MISTAKE. What I presume is the caramel vanilla smells like sandalwood on me, and that is perhaps my most nauseating scent. I despise sandalwood and it’s so inescapable at the moment. That phase lasts too long. The Final dry down is back to a muted creamy/tart scent that Is pleasant but not worth the ride.

I love sweet scents, and roses are definitely among my favorites. Therefore, my expectations for “Can't Get Enough” by Initio were quite high. I was particularly curious about Hedione, a molecule said to have an almost irresistible allure. Vanilla-sweet, floral, and additionally enticing? I just had to test it. The fragrance opens with a citrusy, sparkling freshness that slightly reminds me of mandarin. The beginning feels almost like a flirty eye contact and immediately piques curiosity. But then the rose strikes with full force: young, dark, heavy, velvety, feminine, and dominant - yet it is not alone. Coated with a thick, creamy layer of caramel vanilla pudding, it ruthlessly sweeps away all delicate nuances from the stage. This is no longer a subtle flirt. In my opinion, the scent becomes too intense and open-hearted - almost as if someone were holding a plump, perfectly staged décolletage right in front of your face. Sexy? Certainly for some. However, the seduction does not come across as delicately and charmingly as one might wish. Instead, the fragrance has a distinct synthetic note that does not feel natural at all. This may appeal to some, depending on their preferences. The sillage is so overwhelmingly strong that a friend from the upper floor of the maisonette apartment reacted with a horrified “What have you sprayed again?” - a testament to the atomic scent cloud (even though I only sprayed twice), but also an indication that the seductive effect may not be well received by everyone.

I have never been a big fan of rose scents, but Can't Get Enough has changed my mind.
This fragrance starts with a slightly fresh rose that gradually becomes sweeter over time.
The pepper adds a bit of sparkle.
Towards the end of the scent journey, the rose is enveloped in caramel and vanilla, making it softer and slightly creamy.
This perfume actually makes me addicted.

For all those who enjoy perfumes like Impadia, Guidance EAU DE PARFUM or Hibiscus Mahajád. This fragrance definitely belongs to that family and is one of the closest relatives.. If you don't like any of the perfumes I mentioned, there's no need to test this scent. The fragrance reminds me most of Impadia but...

review_title: It gave me the impression that I was smelling a real rose
review_content: I just tested this perfume. It gave me the impression that I was smelling a real rose. I didn't buy it, because I have 3 other Yves Rocher perfumes from the Eau fraiche range and they are all extremely weak in intensity on the skin. Too bad for them, because everything from this range smells very nice and very natural! So, I don't think I will buy it anytime soon. The bottle looks like a shower oil rather than a perfume. It's feminine. Rating: 8/10

Our garden was half planted by us - and the other half by my mom.

To the observer, however, it formed a unity, as we always planted flowers that harmonized with each other.

So my mom planted the Queen Elisabeth Rose in front of my Ceanothus, which matched well with the delicate blue of the American lilac with its silvery pink.

The silver shimmer of the Queen gave it a distinct optical coolness - and its scent was delicate and fresh.

I find the Queen Elisabeth Rose as Eau Fraiche Rose in the bottle from Rocher.
This rose is the "star" in this Rocher - but without any star attitudes.

Transparent yet clearly it envelops me - accompanied by delicate sparkle - like fairy dust.
This fairy-tale image is evoked in me by the scent.
I also seem to hear the gentle sky-blue Ceanothus - but that may be allowed by my memory.

This blue-pink composition made many passersby linger dreamily at the garden fence.

Eau fraiche Rose has also allowed me to dream of the past.

product_name: L'Eau par Kenzo Eau Indigo pour Homme
review_content:
I'm reading different takes on this and another website, about the coffee note. Some are satisfied, some are not.

I am not impressed with the opening because the coffee just seems to be lacking in authenticity, at least to me.

Other fragrances do a lot better job with coffee, I felt like I had to wait about three hours for this to soften up and allow the sweeter notes to take stage and blend well with the musk.

Not until about the third hour does the harshness of the coffee/wood notes settle down and turn into a great aroma that makes me happy.

I did not notice the peach and currant notes listed until I got this scent in the mail. Those notes had me wondering whether this would end up syrupy and too feminine.

No, not feminine and the peach is not in the forefront, just in case you're wondering.

Maybe spring but I'm not sure about summer.......autumn and winter? Yes.

Seems to have good projection.

product_name: L'Eau par Kenzo Eau Indigo pour Homme
review_title: Amazing, unique, great performance and reasonably priced
review_content:
I really enjoy this fragrance. It is very unique and performs extremely well for the price point as with most Pierre Montale's perfumes. Very well blended and lasts forever.
It is all year rounder and can be worn safely at the office as well.
The dry down is amazing with soft oud coffee aroma that keeps on giving (the dry down to me is similar but not identical to Mancer Aoud Vanille )
8/10 for me

product_name: L'Eau par Kenzo Eau Indigo pour Homme
review_title: No coffee, no oud, still nice
review_content:
I don’t get much coffee in here honestly, but I do appreciate the fact Aoud Cafè is not a sweetish, cloying Starbucks-like artificial coffee bomb like most of (allegedly) coffee-based scents. I smell something vaguely reminiscent of dry, roasted coffee beans, actually a more generic sort of earthy-roasted note quite salty, synthetic and musky, somehow ambery and somehow woody, with a hint of dark and sweet licorice feel (I guess the blackcurrant with something else creates that feeling), and a load of Iso E. Overall, this accord feels like an attempt to build that coffee note: it doesn’t really succeed in my opinion, but it smells nice. The same for oud, which I don’t really get, not even the usual Montale’s “synthetic oud”: just a dry, artificial woody note closer to birch wood. Anyway despite being quite far from its name, I can’t say Aoud Cafè smells bad: oddly enough, and perhaps involuntarily, it shows an unexpected and pleasant sort of “contemporary synthetic blackness”, this meaning a kind of “urban-modern” refinement à la Comme des Garçons Black and that type of scents; the notes are a bit different (more salt here, and also something more flowery), but somehow I thought of that. It has a nice, clean, solid and polished smoky-dark gloominess with a nice hint of colorful grace (the floral note), which is quite pleasant to wear. I bet that re-labeled with some nonsense name under one of those whatever trendy-avantgarde brands (like nu_be’s and that segment of niche) it would be more appreciated.

6,5/10

product_name: L'Eau par Kenzo Eau Indigo pour Homme
review_content:
Mancera Aoud Cafe is not a sweet coffee perfume with the floral note in middle note !!!
This is a must have perfume for gourmand lovers..Lasts almost 9 hours with a decent sillage.
Worth a penny

product_name: L'Eau par Kenzo Eau Indigo pour Homme
review_content:
"That's not how it works," I hear a male voice next to me. Suddenly, the chair beside me is pulled back, a long drink glass is parked next to my cup, while a good-looking guy slides onto the chair.
"I see you're drinking your mocha without a pastis, I couldn't watch that any longer."
Annoyed, I raise an eyebrow and immediately hate the fact that his voice sounds rough and seductive. He looks me in the eyes and a smile creeps onto his face.
"I've been watching you for a while, you're tapping away on your tablet while stressfully drinking one coffee after another, take the drink and call me Tom."
I smile and ask him with sparkling eyes:
"And what kind of universe is it where anis belongs with coffee?"
"That's my world, I invite you to get to know it. You can test it on my lips, or just like this," he pushes the pastis under my nose. And because he is crazy, but cheeky and charming, I take a sip.
Heaven! I had completely forgotten how much I love that licorice taste. It settles on my tongue and mixes with the bitterness of the coffee, wonderful! Afternoons in Marseille cafés flash before me. A light breeze from the flower stalls at the market wafts over to our bistro table, which is in the sun. Friends are chattering together, coffee cups are stacked in the middle, and a fogged jug stands next to the pastis glasses... past hours of leisure.
I open my eyes and see directly into Tom's smiling, knowing face. He is so close to me now that I can perceive his scent, sandalwood and musk, mmh.
"Come eat with me," his gaze is strong, I can feel his heat on my skin and say "Yes!".

"Yes!" I say especially to 'Aoud Café' by Mancera. A fragrance just to my taste. It is a gourmand, with a clear coffee note. In the opening, there is bergamot with the coffee, which ensures that the citrus keeps boredom at bay. It smells as if you are standing in front of a roastery, malty. So, less agreeable than a freshly brewed coffee.
I don't perceive the stated berries at all.
But very, very clearly, licorice comes to the forefront (sweet wood, anis) and this combo is really nice and provides a kind of break.
However, just before this malt/licorice thing runs amok, musk comes soothingly and warmly around the corner and ensures a long-lasting presence.
The big brother from 'Montale' is more uniform and clearer, while this guy here (from the same father) is more unconventional and lively, really great!

P.S. I didn't find any oud. Our oud expert (Manogi) one floor down didn't find any either, which is reassuring.

product_name: L'Eau par Kenzo Eau Indigo pour Homme
review_content:
Coffee beans in a licorice coat were my first thoughts. The scent of licorice hit my nose at the beginning. Strange, I thought. It must be the interplay of the individual fragrance notes. However, very pleasant. The licorice impression quickly faded. Then... darkest coffee beans. Beautiful... and yes, it really does smell like coffee, after I was quite disappointed by Kilian's "Intoxicated." With that one, there’s no coffee from start to finish. Please don’t imagine a coffee cup with sweetened coffee under AC. It’s really dark beans. The scent itself gives a sweet impression overall and in its progression, but the coffee notes are clearly dark. However, they eventually recede into the background, so the fragrance always appears sweet as a whole. Additionally, I now sense an oud scent rising to my nose. Not a harsh, sharply medicinal oud note. A sweetly embedded oud, it smells wonderfully warm on my arm. At first, I thought it was an overall decent scent, but I certainly didn’t have to have it. However, the longer I sniff my arm, the more I like AC. It has developed very beautifully. Aoud Cafe can no longer be broken down into many individual components. It has become a truly wonderful, softly warm overall composition. It even has something cozy about it. Simply wonderfully fitting for the cold winter season. I would have never expected at the beginning that AC would develop into such a pleasantly warm scent. The only critical point to mention here is that the coffee scent recedes significantly after a while. Nevertheless, I will definitely use the 10ml bottle for myself.

The sillage seems to be good. I think one will certainly be noticed as a wearer without taking over the room. The longevity is very good. It lasts well throughout the day. Still detectable on clothing for days.

UPDATE: The longer I own this scent, the more I have come to love it. Additionally, I receive extraordinarily positive feedback for this fragrance. I must now elevate it again.

review_title: No coffee, no oud, still nice
review_content:
I don’t get much coffee in here honestly, but I do appreciate the fact Aoud Cafè is not a sweetish, cloying Starbucks-like artificial coffee bomb like most of (allegedly) coffee-based scents. I smell something vaguely reminiscent of dry, roasted coffee beans, actually a more generic sort of earthy-roasted note quite salty, synthetic and musky, somehow ambery and somehow woody, with a hint of dark and sweet licorice feel (I guess the blackcurrant with something else creates that feeling), and a load of Iso E. Overall, this accord feels like an attempt to build that coffee note: it doesn’t really succeed in my opinion, but it smells nice. The same for oud, which I don’t really get, not even the usual Montale’s “synthetic oud”: just a dry, artificial woody note closer to birch wood. Anyway despite being quite far from its name, I can’t say Aoud Cafè smells bad: oddly enough, and perhaps involuntarily, it shows an unexpected and pleasant sort of “contemporary synthetic blackness”, this meaning a kind of “urban-modern” refinement à la Comme des Garçons Black and that type of scents; the notes are a bit different (more salt here, and also something more flowery), but somehow I thought of that. It has a nice, clean, solid and polished smoky-dark gloominess with a nice hint of colorful grace (the floral note), which is quite pleasant to wear. I bet that re-labeled with some nonsense name under one of those whatever trendy-avantgarde brands (like nu_be’s and that segment of niche) it would be more appreciated.

6,5/10

"That's not how it works," I hear a male voice next to me. Suddenly, the chair beside me is pulled back, a long drink glass is parked next to my cup, while a good-looking guy slides onto the chair.
"I see you're drinking your mocha without a pastis, I couldn't watch that any longer."
Annoyed, I raise an eyebrow and immediately hate the fact that his voice sounds rough and seductive. He looks me in the eyes and a smile creeps onto his face.
"I've been watching you for a while, you're tapping away on your tablet while stressfully drinking one coffee after another, take the drink and call me Tom."
I smile and ask him with sparkling eyes:
"And what kind of universe is it where anis belongs with coffee?"
"That's my world, I invite you to get to know it. You can test it on my lips, or just like this," he pushes the pastis under my nose. And because he is crazy, but cheeky and charming, I take a sip.
Heaven! I had completely forgotten how much I love that licorice taste. It settles on my tongue and mixes with the bitterness of the coffee, wonderful! Afternoons in Marseille cafés flash before me. A light breeze from the flower stalls at the market wafts over to our bistro table, which is in the sun. Friends are chattering together, coffee cups are stacked in the middle, and a fogged jug stands next to the pastis glasses... past hours of leisure.
I open my eyes and see directly into Tom's smiling, knowing face. He is so close to me now that I can perceive his scent, sandalwood and musk, mmh.
"Come eat with me," his gaze is strong, I can feel his heat on my skin and say "Yes!".

"Yes!" I say especially to 'Aoud Café' by Mancera. A fragrance just to my taste. It is a gourmand, with a clear coffee note. In the opening, there is bergamot with the coffee, which ensures that the citrus keeps boredom at bay. It smells as if you are standing in front of a roastery, malty. So, less agreeable than a freshly brewed coffee.
I don't perceive the stated berries at all.
But very, very clearly, licorice comes to the forefront (sweet wood, anis) and this combo is really nice and provides a kind of break.
However, just before this malt/licorice thing runs amok, musk comes soothingly and warmly around the corner and ensures a long-lasting presence.
The big brother from 'Montale' is more uniform and clearer, while this guy here (from the same father) is more unconventional and lively, really great!

P.S. I didn't find any oud. Our oud expert (Manogi) one floor down didn't find any either, which is reassuring.

Part of the "problem" at Marc Antoine Barrois is that their first scent in their long partnership with Quentin Bisch, Ganymede EAU DE PARFUM was so revolutionary and became so popular. It's rare that a fragrance so utterly unique can become such a good seller; generally even fragheads need some roots to the past to ground them so they can enjoy the uniqueness in a controlled environment.

Because of the uniqueness and popularity, I think MAB fell into a sort of "Game of Thrones" syndrome where they needed to try to do the same thing over and over to try and get the same result. Let me explain: in Game of Thrones, in case you haven't watched it, there are lots of huge plot twists and main characters don't necessarily have plot armor protecting them. For the first five seasons, the twists and deaths were enjoyable, but near the end of the show, they seemingly started killing off characters just to show they could, and introducing twists that weren't properly built up, culminating in probably the worst last season, relative to how good the show used to be, of any show at least I've ever watched.

Now Aldebaran isn't all that bad, actually is not bad at all, but I feel like, similar to Game of Thrones, MAB is trying to re-bottle lightning, just releasing strange and out-there scents to try and capture the magic of Ganymede, instead of just releasing stuff that smells good; i.e. killing off characters and introducing plot twists just for the sake of it, instead of writing an actual compelling story. I could be entirely wrong here and M. Barrois is just a fan of these weird edgy scents and pays Quentin Bisch to keep making them.

Aldebaran actually smells like all the notes in the notes listing. Almost too much like them. Photorealistic tuberose, photorealistic paprika/bell pepper. Smooth, sweet tonka bean. Bitter, grassy maté. Do they work together? Kind of. But it just feels unnatural and unnerving. I think that's why there are votes for "synthetic." Each note doesn't smell synthetic at all but the combination is bizarre and like something a robot who's unable to smell would come up with.

None of this is to say it's "bad," per se, just utterly WEIRD. Usually I commend a fragrance for its originality but here it almost works against Aldebaran. I'm giving it a high score because I'm enjoying it for its novelty, but this is definitely not an endorsement for a blind buy. I can very easily see how someone could feel that this is an absolute abomination, and it's like a hair away from that for me. It's one of those that can either be higher than an 8 or lower than a 2 and nothing in between.

review_title: Aldebaran the ancient star that guides to the East
review_content:
It’s the exact scent of a 'gajra', the fresh tuberose flowers that are strung by hand on a thread and sold in indian streets in the morning for 20 roupies, they are worn wrapped around wrists, hair or offered to gods during pooja. Beautiful realistic fragrance: it’s Bombay monsoon, the gajra mingles with the humid air, the warm skin, and the rain ; the flowers soaked in scent and weather. It simply captures this moment of wearing a gajra bracelet all day in Bombay. It's devotional, sensual, nostalgic, sacred and roadside tea boiling at the chai-wala corner smell at once.
Bought a bottle today so I can be wrapped again in those memory of delicious rain-drenched days with gajra in India. After all, Aldebaran is the royal star, the one that is the East. And it really does light the way back to my favourite place in the East!

To the ancient Egyptians, the star of Aldebaran was connected with the eye of Horus, the sky god and king of Egypt.
Four hundred times brighter than the sun, it is represented as the second star of the floral constellation by Marc Antoine Barrois.
Its color is red, often associated with passion, and what flower more appropriate than the tuberose to represent the "star of fire" ?
To describe Aldebaran as a fragrance starring the narcotic flower par excellence would be extremely reductive.
Here we are in front of a creation by Quentin Bisch (and yes, I love him), which strips itself of pleasingness and heads towards an extremely artistic dimension.
A not-so-obvious tuberose, which to its heady notes adds the mate grass (it seems to perceive it in powder form), with nuances that I perceive almost metallic, very particular.
I had to smell it on my skin several times to understand it, because it has a really not obvious construction, and it becomes a real sensory journey.
Go and smell it, it's really particular, it comes out of the box, and you will realize that you will be more and more intrigued by its uniqueness.
Of course in my collection, I wear it when I want to feel indecipherable, unique.
And here I mention the mystique of Egyptian art , which represents it perfectly .

Loudly for the people in the back: being different for the sake of it doesn't make you cool. This feels like a moniker that I should adapt any time a new release comes out from French "designer niche house" Marc-Antoine Barrois. Just like with Tilia last year, the product offered isn't that far from what is already available in the market, yet somehow there's enough here to stay in the realm of their brand image.

I've experienced the Aldebaran twice now and the difference is quite pronounced on paper vs. on skin. The scent opens with a very strong green-aromatic floral tonality, flanked by a puzzling smoky-woody touch. I believe this is the listed maté note which I've also experienced in this fashion before in Clive Christian's Matsukita. Shortly thereafter, the notes and accords settle with the scent mostly smelling of creamy tuberose, flanked by a green backbone and light sweetness from the tonka.

The contrast of notes comes off fairly artsy relative to where niche perfumery is nowadays, but quirkiness doesn't mean the product has good quality nor wearability. I'd even argue that in many cases, it just leaves you with an outdated product. Just last year Maison Crivelli had a strong release in the tuberose realm with Tubéreuse Astrale, a fragrance that also features osmanthus and carrot seed, i.e. notes that co-star well with the tuberose. Meanwhile, Aldebaran doesn't have those notes which is a key reason why this scent comes off like a more typical tuberose-neroli fragrance with an added tonka. The strength of the scent is on-par with the house's other products and the blending isn't as rough, i.e. the synthetic nature isn't left as exposed; but the product just doesn't deliver anything besides loud & rarer profile; both of which are categories where the aforementioned Crivelli is superior.

Debates around niche vs designer perfumes are everywhere online.
Everyone has their own opinion, their own interpretation.
I once read that since Marc-Antoine Barrois is also a fashion brand, it should be classified as "designer."
If your definition of niche leads you to put the house behind Ganymede in the "designer" category, then maybe your definition needs a little rethinking.
With Aldebaran, at least, there will be no question: this is pure niche.
A floral composition, touched with paprika or green pepper notes, maté, tonka bean...
Doesn't ring any bells? That's normal.
As often with true niche perfumes, the listed notes only tell part of the story.
Aldebaran is a perfume you must smell to truly understand — a divisive scent, a discreet yet passionate tuberose.
Unique.

Unfortunately, the scent starts off extremely tuberose and, in my opinion, has nothing in common with Blanche Bête. An overwhelming wave of tuberose hits me head-on, white flowers quickly join...

review_content: Aldebaran - what a blast. A spray from the bottle and an enormous tuberose cloud immediately fills the room, but wait, it’s not good, no, it’s terrible, help! Quickly, get me out of here.. Luckily, I received a sample and thought, well, if it comes to that again, I’ll take my time applying it to my skin BUT for me, the opening is almost unbearable. Afterwards, it becomes...

These creations by Quentin Bisch with this slightly higher budget are truly great. Even with a somewhat smaller budget, Mr. Bisch can create good things, but in this price range, his potential seems fully realized. Mr. Bisch makes all the fragrances for this...

Especially at the beginning, Aldebaran knows how to stand out and feels particularly niche. Over time, however, things change a bit. So for those who are put off, give it some time. While others dismiss it as cumbersome or even unsympathetic, it immediately triggered something in me that I can hardly put into words. The first impression is indeed unusual: cool, metallic, almost repellent. But that’s exactly what...

Every year, the fragrance house MAB surprises us with some unique scent creations that I have never smelled before. This year is all about the tuberose, but not subtly NO, it’s the full blast As already expected in "Tubéreuse Astrale | Maison Crivelli," we are greeted with a nuclear performance here. The fragrance starts off slightly less sweet than the Tubéreuse Astrale...
