review_content: What flows forth rises in the first molecule, does not tell me it comes from far away. The journey begins in an intermediate state. In the ethereal stream between plant body and light form. From the stream, a bio signature of lost earth tears itself away, preserved in sparkling elven white. Born in earthly garden fantasies. It appears like a masked presence - veiled like a...

Quite interesting, but not for me. The first 10 minutes are way too overpowering, but it gets much better over time. A lot of tuberose and especially at the beginning a lot of paprika and mate, somehow reminiscent of essential oils. After about 20 minutes, the paprika and mate fade a bit, and it becomes slightly sweet due to the tonka bean and definitely more pleasant. You can...

review_title: A typical Quentin that doesn't want/need to please
review_content: This new fragrance from Barrois is hard to categorize. The tuberose comes across as more green than sweet. On top of that, there’s an unprecedented and unexpected kick of red pepper that adds a spicy zest to the scent. Either you love it - or you're out. It's not a fragrance for the mainstream, not a crowd-pleaser, and definitely not a blind buy. But for those who are tired...

Aldebaran surprised me a lot. I can understand that some people might not like it; it is quite special, even more so for me than Ganymede. Aldebaran reminds me very much of the scent of wintergreen. And also a bit of that devil's claw bath additive from Tetesept, somehow crazy, is it only possible like this? From the spiciness, it also reminds me of Ganymede, but with...

review_title: Specialty: Moth dusted with paprika powder.
review_content: No thanks. absolute white floral nightmare. I don’t understand the hype around the brand right now, maybe because of Mr. Bisch but it’s just not for me. Powdery, white, cold, dark, and very dry. dry paprika powder. The scent reminded me of a moth that haunted me every night as soon as I closed my eyes. It is really very strong and has top sillage - I only sprayed it on a test strip and placed it in the corner of the table, and in the evening when I came home, the scent had already spread throughout the entire hallway. And my apartment is only 40 m²...

Upon the first spray, the top note reminded me of JPG Classique, which I adored in my 20s and still enjoy to some extent. After that, the fragrance develops differently; it becomes a bit herbaceous, with a subtle sweet note and something creamy in the background. After about an hour, a note emerges on my skin that I can't quite describe, but it becomes somewhat overwhelming. It behaves on my skin similarly to Tilia. I receive compliments with this fragrance, but some component bothers my own nose...

review_title: Tuberose in a completely different way ,,,
review_content: My ultimate nemesis when it comes to fragrance notes is definitely tuberose, no question about it, but this scent has something so interesting that I must definitely bow to the nose, Quentin Bisch, who created this fragrance.. The scent opens with 100% green tuberose, which comes across as slightly "meaty." I have to admit I have to endure the first 10 minutes, but what...

I recently sniffed my way through Munich and Aldebaran was also on my wishlist, as I was looking for tuberose that day among other things.
I liked this new fragrance from Marc-Antoine Barrois very much from the first moment. Why is this scent so underrated? I find the interplay of the fragrance notes extremely successful and pleasing. You get a rich tuberose here, and I am a fan of tonka bean anyway. Mate as the icing on the cake does a fantastic job here. The listed paprika shouldn't be overemphasized; it's actually only used for balancing, as I learned from the very dedicated fragrance consultant at Beck.
I find the longevity of Aldebaran to be fantastic, and I also rate the sillage highly.
So come on, dear ones, give it another test... for me, this fragrance is moving from the watch list to the wish list for autumn.

A really cool scent once again from the house of Barrois. Aldebaran is intensely positive, and definitely a compliment-giver. I don't usually like tuberose that much, but here it fits perfectly into the composition of, for example, mate tea (freshness) and tonka bean (warmth). The ensemble somehow reminds me of the Garden of Eden, just as one imagines it (in this case probably on Aldebaran). The scent is above average present on the skin. Two sprays are enough for the evening, and probably just one for the office. So far, everyone has liked it, and I certainly do too.

When it comes to Marc-Antoine Barrois, I don’t think long - I just buy. Everything that comes from this brand immediately piques my interest, my trust, and… leads to a blind purchase. That was also the case with Aldebaran.

But this time, the first encounter was not easy. With the first breath - no love at first sight. Not even with the second. Only on the third try did the fragrance begin to unfold differently. Deeper, warmer, fuller. And then I realized: Aldebaran is not one of those fragrances that enchant immediately. It demands time, attention, and silence. And yes, this scent does not want to please everyone, nor can it.

Its composition is complex, somewhat distant, with its own inner logic and movement. Not a fleeting romance, but a slow infatuation. And now I know for sure - I am not disappointed. It is more about respect. And a growing interest.

review_title: From the Tectonic Quality of Ambered Resins
review_content:
I met Thierry Autour, whom some (like himself) describe as a scientist, while others see more of a madman, in a national park in North America at a location that is difficult to access for civilization, the whereabouts of which I promised to keep secret. The texture and temperature of the soil here are ideal for his olfactory experiments, he assured me. Some time ago, he had buried various resins from North and South America, Egypt, and Thailand to examine their, as he said, tectonic qualities. Due to the anomaly of the soil, the resins would never harden and would remain in constant motion, sometimes even merging and separating like in a lava lamp, he described enthusiastically. However, the olfactory experience when uncovering the resins is unique, as the aromas would gradually dissipate after a while, so it is an honor for me, and I should close my eyes, he smiled mischievously as he knelt on the damp ground with a small shovel and a root brush and began to make the first careful digs into the soil. I closed my eyes.
At first, I perceived a warm-spicy earthy scent of patchouli, which seemed to mix with a slightly sharp-green vetiver. Both scents blended quite pleasantly, seeming to excitingly complement each other in their contrast. That is just the smell of the earth and the grass here, Thierry laughed, and I heard him scraping further.
About five minutes later, a slightly smoky, resinous, minimally cinnamon-vanilla aroma took over, which vaguely reminded me of gingerbread, and Thierry assured me that this was the South American Peru and Tolubalsam resins that evoked these notes and liked to merge with each other during their tectonic movement to enhance their aromas.
After another ten minutes, the scent lightened a bit, acquiring a slightly medicinal resinous character, which Thierry attributed to the benzoin resin, now mixing with the smell of the damp meadow. To me, it still smelled of fresh vetiver. This impression now shifted with a distant cumin-like scent that mingled with the cinnamon-vanilla resin and seemed to be glazed with warm honey. This was now the labdanum resin, which elicited this impression from the Peru and Tolubalsam, Thierry indulged, before he gave me a one-hour geological lecture on the peculiarities of resin tectonics, to which I paid no attention due to the spicy-warm enjoyment, into which the scent of balsamic-tobacco-like amber was slowly blending more and more. This amber scent arose from the separation of cis-abienol from the North American balsam fir, Thierry lectured, and came to me with chemical soil processes that I could not follow for the life of me; I focused instead on the increasingly sweet, warm-spicy amber scent that lingered for many hours before slowly fading away.
I could now open my eyes again, Thierry said, trying to be serious, to which I did just that. Laughing to tears, he held out a bottle of Ambre Mystère to me. These perfume junkies believed even the most absurd theories as long as it was about discovering new olfactory compositions, he chuckled, resin tectonics and aroma archaeology, he could hardly contain himself. I could keep the bottle, he finally said, recommending the scent for autumn to spring and noting that the sillage was rather moderate, which I had already noticed myself.

no!
This perfume is by no means an ordinary amber.

But let's start from the beginning: Thanks to dear KatRedhead, I have the pleasure of owning a sample of this fragrance. I tested it out of curiosity right away. Since a wooow! is rather meager for a comment, here’s a bit more detail:
The first impression is (of course) amber, heavy gray amber. Gray, yes, but not of the extremely meaty kind, rather with golden flecks like fresh, yellow honey. I suspect that it is the labdanum that gives the perfume, despite all its heaviness, a lightness and almost a sense of ease. After a relatively short while, the patchouli joins in, grounding the scent and together with delicious, smoky vanilla, creating a fragrance harmony that could come straight from paradise.

The sillage could be overwhelming, but this honey note keeps the fragrance from being overpowering despite its enveloping presence. As for longevity: It exceeds all expectations! A small spray this morning, and after washing my hands and showering countless times since then, the perfume is still clearly noticeable.

Conclusion: Ambre Mystere has made me a new fan and will definitely find a place in my collection!

After "Poudre d'Iris," "Ambre Mystere" was to be my second test candidate from "Autour du Parfum." True to the motto "You catch mice with bacon and you catch me with amber," I couldn't pass up this scent!

Given the name, I expected a heavy, mystically dark, almost black amber like the one I experienced with Michele Bergman's "Black Amber."

That expectations are not always met is part of the nature of things. Unfortunately, this was also the case here: Instead of what I expected, I encountered "only" a normal amber scent, one I've come across several times before. A spicy amber representative resting on vanilla and patchouli.

A true scent development doesn't seem to occur for me. I also can't really pick out the individual fragrance components. What is clearly present from the beginning to the end is amber (relatively heavy and expansive), vanilla (slightly smoky), and patchouli (earthy, but not musty).

All in all, a good and solid scent that, however, raises greater expectations with its name than it can ultimately fulfill. Perhaps the name should symbolize that amber has something mystical about it? But it doesn't matter.

What is certain is that AM is a good unisex fragrance that lasts long, can be worn in any season and for any occasion, and also offers a solid price-performance ratio.

All starts from the opening where the two types of tobaccos used (Virginian and Bulgarian) will be perceptible, in combination with saffron, spices and a bit of cocoa to give a chocolatey vibe, which will transition towards the fulcrum of the composition, the oud...

To my nose, the most evident oud profile is the Cambodian variety, which will begin with something "wild" like a note of hay for a few minutes, then accentuate on nuances of tobacco first and purple fruits to follow.

The fruity nuance will be somewhat continued by the Thai oud, a sorta of sparring partner, which will veer towards woody territories in the dry down, accompanied by sandalwood.

I do not perceive Filipino oud distinctly, perhaps because of my culture to broaden, although I think it is giving something delicately incensy to the whole.

That said, the result is commendable

A sickeningly sweet synthetic fruit bomb suitable mostly for teenagers. You could wear this all year round, but I prefer you didn't.

A complete failure to me. This fragrance opens heavy and sweet, with lots of candy fruits. There's a sour note from the passion fruit and it fizzes a bit. It's just so, so extremely synthetic that it reminds me of a cheap hairspray, and almost gives me a headache. On clothing the passion fruit is more defined than on skin.

There's some bitterness in the dry down, which leans more to the resinous than zesty side. Ans a little bit of musk peeps around the corner. It shifts a bit from the candy-like sweetness to something containing citrus notes. There's a hidden flower in there that I can't place that makes it all somewhat softer together with the vanilla, but don't expect miracles. throughout the longevity of this scent the hairspray is still a dominant factor. Don't like. At all.

review_title: A slightly more fruity/synthetic version of D&G The One!
review_content: I can only compare it with The One Edp, which I own a bottle of. In the heart notes, more similarities appear, but in the base they again become very easy to separate. Black Amber has more of a tangy vibe+has that tiare 'note in it. I'd say longevity is better on my skin with Zara. But no way near as smooth & creamy as The One. I could wear Zara Black Amber every day without problem, it easy to like!! Both scents have their advantages.

During my shopping tour today, I also found my way to Zara and stumbled upon their small selection of perfumes...
My gaze immediately landed on a small, simple bottle (by the way, not the one pictured above; the fragrance is also available in a transparent, small, elongated, narrow bottle). Quite appealing in itself with classic charm.
Oh... Was there something? Amber? And then also Black?
My interest was piqued. So I sprayed it directly on my forearm.
I expected something dark, heavy, perhaps in the direction of the Prada Amber fragrances. But I was mistaken...
On my skin, it immediately developed into an artificial sweet fruit bomb.
I could hardly concentrate on my shopping hunt as the plastic fruits were hitting me around the ears!
If we were to consider only the sillage neutrally, I would place it in the middle range.
I couldn't pick out any individual notes. I found the half hour I endured with this fragrance very exhausting and was glad when I could wash it off my arm at the next best opportunity.
What remained was indeed a hint of amber with a touch of powdery vanilla...
But "Black" was not even this last remaining hint of fragrance for me.
Too bad Zara, the name unfortunately does not live up to its promise.

For me, Zara's dupes are the best! And this perfume does not disappoint my nose either. Those who like The One by D&G will also love Black Amber... Juicy fruity-orange and at the same time creamy, vanillic, soft. It reminds me a bit of the cream orange ice cream Ed von Schleck from my childhood. The longevity is average, but manageable at this price.

Dolce&Gabbana The One was my signature scent for a long, long time. I needed only it and wanted only it.

This fragrance from Zara strongly reminds me of The One, but with a slightly fruitier note due to the passion fruit.

For the price, I think you can't go wrong. It continually brings back memories that I associate with The One. In the summer, I really enjoy wearing Black Amber and layering it with fragrances that contain a lot of musk, as I find that it harmonizes really well and is the perfect combination for hot summer days and evenings.

Sillage and longevity are average, but for the price, it meets my expectations 100%.

review_title: A splendid journey into the darkest abysses
review_content:
Deep Ocean Amber is not a marine, but a splendid journey into the darkest abysses, with the depth and light salinity of ambergris blending with warm, sensual notes, among which ambrette seeds stand out. Slightly camphorated notes immerse the fragrance in a unique, dark and magnetic atmosphere, making it a fragrance that went beyond any idea I might have had when reading its name or the olfactory pyramid.
Well-balanced, intense, wonderful.
Like the legendary city of Atlantis underwater, shining despite the depths of the abyss.
If you love intense, original and enveloping fragrances, you will be enchanted.

I welcome the Sospiro brand to Parfumo after years of moderator tomfoolery with a review of their only 2023 release Deep Ocean Amber. Sospiro has another 3 releases coming next year that they teased at both Cannes TFWA and ScentXplore, so be on the look out (one of them is a cherry gourmand fragrance).

Impressions as I go through the wear, without looking at the notes: Warm spicy & floral right off the top. I think that is violet...? I naturally started to think it was a twist on Oud Satin Mood EAU DE PARFUM, sans the prominent sweetness. But then, I began to notice "Angels' Share | Kilian". At least in the air, the balsamic amber you have here is the exact same one used in "Angels' Share | Kilian", albeit it clearly lacks the prominent sweetness of both OSM & AS. In the deep drydown, the scent has a hint of cinnamon which further showcases vibes of the aforementioned Kilian. But there is something in the back here that smells dry-animalic-woody, I am guessing it's styrax.

After pyramid: I think amber is clearly the #1 accord here, so the benzoin & labdanum are prominent. The name feels like a double entendre, because the ambergris (listed as a base note) I'd say is not as evident. I did some of this testing indoors and some of it outdoors - what I'd say is that the amber here smells like "Angels' Share | Kilian" *indoors* with a hint of sweetness (but it's moderate, unlike AS & OSM) and outdoors, the amber smells more like those from Carner Barcelona.

Evolution: Aggregate scent is always led by the amber accord. Up-close it first smelled warm spicy & floral, perhaps mildly boozy (about 5 minutes into the wear). Then the styrax really kicks in at about 10-15 minutes and is noticeable for the rest of it as the initial elemi-amber combo dies down a bit, giving it a mild animalic flair.

Very hard to bring up comparables, but think Oud Satin on 0.5x strength + styrax or Angels' Share - sweetness + styrax. I'd say moderate-to-strong sillage for the first 2-3 hours and then the scent dies down, lasting around 9-10 hours. Overall, a bit too much styrax in the base which takes away from the "good, but not great" opening. €330/100ml doesn't capture my attention. I rate it a 6.0/10 - it's the epitome of average product.

I have almost never encountered a fragrance that is so difficult to describe in terms of its scent. This is the case with "Deep Ocean Amber | Sospiro," even though the name is almost self-explanatory and one wouldn't think it could be so multifaceted and diverse.

The scent reminds me a bit of "40 Knots | Xerjoff," but has a much deeper composition. While 40 Knots smells to my nose like a breeze of sea air from the North Sea - spicy-salty cool - Deep Ocean Amber is more reminiscent of a breeze of sea air from the Mediterranean. Carried by the hot midday sun, it sweeps over resinous trees and spices from the neighboring villages, warming the skin.

Deep Ocean Amber starts off resinous dark and slightly smoky, reminiscent of incense. Gradually, the nuances that evoke a spicy wind appear; like spices carried by the wind over long distances, somewhat dissipating but never completely disappearing. Styrax and violet create slightly floral nuances that allow the wearer to dream away; to the sea, into the sun.
After a while, amber and benzoin open up with an incomparable warmth. The spicy wind is warmed and carried further by the hot sun. It penetrates directly to the heart and warms the spirit like the summer sun.

An incredibly wonderful, warm fragrance; multifaceted from smoky-spicy to floral and warming, it offers a lot. I wouldn't recommend blind buying it due to the resinous-smoky notes, but testing it is highly recommended.

This fragrance has no review? That pretty much describes why it is so magical for me.

It flies completely under the radar, appears extremely rarely in the ticker, and when I exchange thoughts with my fragrance friends here, it is rarely known.
But is it because it is "redundant"?
In my opinion, absolutely not.
If you are active in this community, exchanging ideas, sending fragrance samples back and forth, you inevitably find yourself in the lovely situation of being able to test new fragrances of all kinds repeatedly. However, this fragrance was not sent to me as an addition; somehow, I became aware of this scent on my own. I ordered a sample because it sounded totally intriguing, and on the other hand, the brand Sospiro has often convinced me. And so it does again now.

Starting with the extremely beautiful name of the fragrance and the black bottle, which looks simply great in my collection.

The Deep Ocean Amber initially starts off extremely resinous and smoky, and I must admit that I was a bit put off at first sniff. My first thought was, uh, it smells pretty dark down there.
At 6:45 AM, I sprayed it three times, and the Deep Ocean Amber came on with a power I did not expect. Almost a bit too powerful.
I like to smell good and unique, but I prefer not to be overwhelming.
I think 2 sprays might have been better. So, I make my way to work comfortably, and after about a 35-minute drive, I perceive the fragrance quite differently. Sure, it is still smoky and resinous, but it feels much rounder now.
I no longer feel like I am overwhelming my surroundings with this scent.
On the contrary, the longer time passes, the more pleasing this fragrance becomes. After about 2 hours, the amber has asserted itself, and you hardly notice that smoky note that bothered me at first.
A feeling of well-being spreads, which I have only experienced with a few fragrances in this form. Often, fragrances annoy me after a while, but not this one.

The dry down is the truly magical part of this fragrance. An invisible presence that no longer screams but whispers, yet is certainly perceived by everyone around you.
I have only felt a similar majestic presence before with Nefs or "Enigma pour Homme / Creation-E pour Homme (Parfum) | Roja Parfums." And those who know these two fragrances understand what I mean.

The longevity of the Deep Ocean Amber is truly astonishing. Applied in the morning, you can easily still perceive this fragrance on yourself in the evening. Easily 8 to 12 hours.

After a conversation in my boss's office, she later approached me again to tell me that this is the best fragrance I have worn so far.
And my boss is certainly accustomed to high-quality fragrances because of me.

I am firmly convinced that this fragrance will soon find great acclaim in the community. Although I wouldn't mind if it stayed just as it is now. ↔
Anyone looking for a secret weapon away from the mainstream will not be disappointed here.

I will never leave the deep sea again.

Sooo fooled by this one. First impression (the opening) is something bitter and green. Really bitter, as artemisia bitter. I don't know where this comes from, maybe an old sample or a really strong oud? Development brings a touch of pleasant, creamy sweetness and a different olfactory composition, one closer to that one you would imagine just by reading the notes. It's a good quality fragrance, longlasting, but if you expect something sugary sweet, tropical or "coconut sunscreen vibe", don't be disappointed when you find none of this here. Maybe a hint of it in the drydown. :-D This is masculine, bitter and serious, but nevertheless beautiful and different. I like it.

I didn't want to bother with Joop, because I perceive it as a cheap brand and therefore do not expect quality, but I got my hands on a sample, so here goes. The cons listed are mostly on point. The branding is bad, it's a unisex fragrance and there's nothing icy about it. Well, there is a short moment of iciness right after the opening, but that's it. The opening is mostly bubblegum. It quickly settles into a smell of a hairdresser. If you don't know what I'm talking about, it's a damp, artificial, cloying smell, here coming probably from the plum and tobacco. If I wanted to find this barber scent, I'm sure I wouldn't be able to, but look - it found me.

Read more of my perfume reviews at The Scent Stories: thescentstories.substack.com

With "Joop! Homme," it's back on track! The pink classic was never really gone, but it definitely lost some steam in the 2000s. Now, however, the flankers and offshoots seem to be popping up seemingly bought and (un)asked for - and some of them are even recommendable, like the recent black "Absolute." Even if it had hardly anything to do with the original and should have actually been released under a new name. And sure, there are a few misses, like the "Sport" belly flop, but overall, this potent king of yesteryear is definitely back on deck and is managing to keep its name. So what does this new "Ice" have to offer? A cool guy or a chilling disappointment?

"Joop! Homme Ice" has again very little to do with the pink (attention-grabber) of back then, maybe in its syrupy base sweetness. Otherwise, it's more of a musty-interesting (and somehow citrusy) tobacco/cardamom scent, where I have almost zero "icy" associations, and therefore I find the name not particularly fitting. The scent and I, however, fit together quite a bit better. A rather weird combo of scratchiness and balm, of ashtray and shisha, of gray suit and Hubba Bubba. This will surely make some people really nauseous; you can tear it apart in the air if you want or if you can't come to terms with it. I find it exciting, charming, daring. At least that. At least. Cardamom and orange blossom both make a strong showing, neither wanting to let the other take the lead. Somewhere in the vast no man's land between "Fleur du Male," "La Nuit de L’Homme," and "Tabarome," thoughts of "Hugo" or even "Tabac Original" come to mind. Just with this thick sugar glaze that contradictorily lifts the otherwise rather herbaceous DNA, rejuvenates it, and almost makes it club-ready. I somehow like it. Maybe it's because I'm a fan of plums, and these also hover above everything. Juicy, dripping, sticky. But never annoying me. A cool scent. Just never even the slightest hint of icy...

Bottle: somewhat boring blue, at least fitting to the theme, usual shape
Sillage: not as loud as the pink one, but louder than some other flankers
Longevity: doesn't disappear too quickly - 6-9 hours

Conclusion: interesting, distinctive, sweet, slightly citrusy, with clear Joop Homme DNA. And yet quite different. Finally something daring. Not everyone will like it. I do. Somehow. Odd hybrid. Attractive or repulsive. Give it a test!

It's not so easy to test a fragrance in the current situation, but this one can be easily smelled even through 3 masks.
I was a bit disturbed when I saw what was happening at Douglas on a completely normal Wednesday at 2 PM.....BUT, of course, a nice lady came up to me right away and asked if she could help me....So I pulled out my phone and showed her 5 screenshots of fragrances that currently interest me.
Besides this one, there was also the WRITER, the AQUAMAN by Davidoff, and 2 from Yves Saint Laurent.
By the way, I was wearing the AVIATOR by Paris Bleu today.....I applied 3 more fragrances to test, but the only one that really stuck in my nose was the Joop Homme ICE.
In my opinion, it's an exceptionally good spring/summer fragrance, but it is definitely UNISEX.
To be honest, I find it quite difficult to describe this fragrance, so I will categorize it instead.
Fresh / Sweet / Fruity / Woody / Aquatic with a hint of powder...that's probably the best way to describe it.
The sillage is STRONG, comparable to UR HOMME, and the longevity also seems to be quite good, as even after showering just now, it is still noticeably present.
However, a direct comparison to the regular HOMME cannot be made here; it's not like you can just throw HOMME and COOL WATER into a pot and come out with HOMME ICE.
TESTING is definitely worth it here!!!
Addendum from 13.07.2020
In direct comparison with the "normal" Joop Homme, the sillage is not quite as strong...that's why I changed my rating from 9 to 8...but it is still strong.

review_title: Something off about the name but still good!
review_content: As a child of the 80s and 90s, I have known the Joop brand for a long time. My parents wore the pink original in the early 90s and were huge fans of this strong fragrance at the time. I still remember that before my parents went out, they would always spray themselves and left behind a pink cloud of scent after leaving the apartment. This lingered for ages, and as a child, I was already very taken with this fragrance and would always sniff after it. Many years later, when I was old enough and had the corresponding pocket money, there was always a Joop fragrance in the house alongside Dior's Fahrenheit. My first Joop was the green GO! I celebrated it back then. With its wonderful rhubarb note, it was a rather unique scent at the time, with moderate longevity and sillage. I also once had Joop Wild in the form of a sample, but I didn't buy it (I can't remember why). Since then, a lot of time has passed, and I had been less impressed with Joop fragrances as I focused more on other brands. Recently, I was browsing Fragrantica again and discovered the blue brother of the original. Joop Ice in beautiful blue and then also with plum?! It was immediately clear that I had to test it. My expectations were rather restrained, along the lines of, well... it will probably be a typical blue shower gel scent with Joop DNA. So, I took the opportunity when I found it during my last shopping trip in a perfume store and gave it a chance. That was a good decision because Joop is really not bad, and I ended up buying it right away. The opening is characterized by a fruity, slightly sour, and subtly cool accord, which in no way has anything to do with Ice. How Joop came up with the name is a mystery to me. The name Ice would fit the bottle better than the content. Nevertheless, it starts off with a nice fresh kick in the first few minutes. Once the citrus fruits have faded a bit, it becomes slightly sweet in the top note, which personally reminds me immediately of chewing gum. After about an hour, we reach the heart, and the fragrance transitions into a subtle sweetness, still accompanied by a bit of freshness. I don't perceive the stated tobacco here, but I do pick up a bit of cardamom. The base gradually settles in, and sandalwood and cardamom come together. Here, I find that one can definitely draw slight parallels to the original. The longevity for me is 10h+ with 4 sprays, depending on the weather. The sillage is very good, and I received compliments even after 2-3 hours and with 4 sprays on my neck. Speaking of likability, the fragrance itself has been very well received so far. Compliments are definitely in the cards with this Joop. In summary, it can be said that Joop has not reinvented the wheel here but has released a very nice and rounded everyday freshie. I think it will be a good alternative for office and leisure. Definitely give it a try; maybe it will appeal to some just as much as it does to me.

This fragrance belongs to the clean scents and has subtle similarities to Prada l'homme; unlike Prada l'homme, this scent does not remind me of a high-quality soap but rather of a fruity/fresh men's shower gel.

What stands out to me is the plum, probably not least because I absolutely love this note. The orange blossom, which is not as prominent, slightly reminds me of the orange note that also resonates in Joop Homme, even though these two fragrances have no other similarities.
The components that would be classified as aromatic and spicy (tobacco, cardamom, sandalwood) remain very much in the background in this fragrance, and in the case of cardamom, it supports the projecting freshness. The blend of clean freshness and subtle spice makes the scent feel synthetic, but not in a cheap way.

Personally, I see this fragrance as an alternative to Prada l'homme if you are a bit younger or looking for a summery alternative, and I can recommend it without hesitation in those cases.

The scent is FRUITY, has a certain FRESHNESS from the cold "ICE" (the name fits perfectly!), and has taken on the SWEETNESS of the original Joop homme. Imagine a freezer filled with frozen fruits; you can also smell the natural grape sugar sweetness of the fruits. That's how the scent smells to me. You wear this fragrance, and you smell like a walking freezer full of frozen...

JOOP! Homme Ur-DNA from 1989 is present, while the 89 fragrance has "suffered" in recent years (color and scent), especially in sweetness (the 89 version reminded many of sweet cherries) and color (previously more reddish). JOOP! Homme Ice possesses this "original" sweet cherry scent that is not dominated or overshadowed by cinnamon. It also slightly reminds of the (failed)...

Joop Homme Ice EdT is a flanker of the classic Joop Homme. The original DNA is definitely perceptible, but the sweetness is not quite as overpowering. That always put me off with the original Joop Homme. You can really only wear that one rarely and with a very subtle dosage. Joop Homme Ice can be worn on more occasions and can be dosed normally. You mainly smell the plum, with...

I tested the new Joop on the left and the Prada L´homme on the right today at Drogerie Müller. At 2:30 PM, I sprayed both. The scent is almost entirely similar to the Prada. Very clean, like fresh laundry. Only the intensity is at least one level below that of Prada. Personally, I like it a lot. At a retailer N...o, it is currently available for €42.00 minus 20% discount...

review_title: Unfortunately just a headache for me
review_content:
Joop! Homme Ice opens just as the name promises: cool, fresh, fruity, sweet. I can't pick out any specific fruits here, the plum overshadows everything. Not a bad opening, ideal for spring. Unfortunately, after the drydown, the freshness disappears, and the Ice is gone, it has probably melted. It gets sweeter and sweeter, tobacco and sandalwood join in, and eventually, it’s just a strongly sweet mishmash that unfortunately gives me a headache. Longevity and sillage are quite good, you can still noticeably smell the fragrance after 5-6 hours, washing it off hardly helps.
For me, a blind buy that didn't work out, but it's not a bad scent either; the original Homme DNA can be detected in the background, definitely worth a try for fans of fruity-sweet fragrances.
The bottle is nothing special, fits well in the hand, and as another user noted, it's certainly not the ugliest on the shelf ^^

I came across this fragrance through a YouTube video and immediately bought it blind at my trusted drugstore. I was told that Joop Homme Ice smells like a sweet and simultaneously fresh plum. I can only confirm this statement. The scent really does smell like a super fruity/sweet plum, and the freshness is really well done. The longevity and sillage are average (longevity about 6-7 hours for me). The bottle is relatively basic, the blue glass looks nice but is nothing really special. The price is also absolutely fair for the fragrance; for €30 you get a lovely fresh, sweet, and fruity plum scent. Joop Homme Ice is great for summer days. This perfume is a top everyday scent that fits almost all situations and is not off-putting or too intrusive. It’s simply a great all-rounder.

review_title: Fabric Softener with Plum to Spray On
review_content: Admittedly, the title of my review may somewhat belittle the scent from Joop. However, that is not necessarily the case. Since I also enjoy evaluating the bottles, I’ll start with that. The slightly rounded body is of course familiar from the original scent "Homme" with its characteristic black plastic cap. The light blue content fits very well with the overall appearance....

Bottle: Very well made with especially a really good sprayer. In my opinion, a frosted glass bottle would have suited the scent very well. Scent: Joop Homme Ice starts off really fresh, citrusy, fruity, and icy. I really like the opening! As it develops, the plum comes out more, and I also get a real fresh laundry fabric softener vibe. A cool scent for spring/summer. I can't...

review_title: TOP flanker from the house of Joop!
review_content:
Until recently, I hadn't had this flanker from the house of Joop! on my radar. Summer was just around the corner, and I was looking for an addition to my summer fragrances. Could it be that I had neither tested nor purchased this Joop! Homme Ice so far? This plum scent in the top note piqued my curiosity. I quickly consulted Dr. Google to find the best possible price, and lo and behold... the fragrance was discontinued! Not a single affordable offer available in the depths of the world wide web. But luckily, there is this wonderful place called parfumo.de. After I initiated a search, it didn't take long for a very nice Parfumo member to help me out.

Joop! remains true to its line in terms of bottle design within the Homme series. And that's a good thing - because I've liked this design from the very beginning! The similarity of the flanker Joop! Homme Ice to the classic Joop! Homme EAU DE TOILETTE is unmistakable. However, when you hold the 80ml Joop! Homme Ice in your hands, you will notice that there are some marginal changes in the design. In any case, the bottle feels wonderful in the hand. Quality glass and a very good sprayer round off the first positive impression. Well done!

A wonderful freshness bursts forth from the very good atomizer at the opening, filling the surroundings with a great freshness and a pleasant sweetness, along with a certain fruitiness from the plum. I also think I can smell the muscatel sage. Wow - I think to myself... great top note that I didn't expect! After the first great impression, tobacco and sandalwood join in as the fragrance develops. These two players give the scent more depth and longevity. This combination really harmonizes very, very well. The fragrance suggests to the consumer, through the "Ice" in its name, a freshness similar to "Terre d'Hermès Eau Givrée | Hermès," which is definitely not the case. Nevertheless, this freshie from the house of Joop! is a summer fragrance that works practically everywhere. Not at all overpowering and super pleasant for those around.

Regarding longevity, I can report that the scent lasts really long for an EdT. For example, it held up for 6-8 hours yesterday at 34°C. Towards the end, it didn't have great sillage, but every now and then a strong breeze comes through, and you notice... it's still there!

Conclusion: Thumbs up! This flanker is more than successful - a wonderful summer fragrance with a unique selling point! Such a scent combination, not least thanks to the plum, is, in my opinion, not found again on the market. From my perspective, it's truly a shame that this Joop! Homme Ice was taken off the market. It deserved to be tested and worn by even more Parfumo members. Because it would have been a great alternative/change in many collections. Totally underrated!!!

review_title: Joop Homme Ice - unfortunately not the quality of Joop Homme!
review_content: Anyone who thinks, like I do, that because Joop Homme has good longevity and a decent sillage, they can't go wrong with this scent, is mistaken. I will rate the scent itself an 8, but longevity and sillage only deserve a maximum of 5 points each. Really a shame. I briefly tested the scent in our perfumery, was thrilled, and unfortunately bought it immediately. But after the first wear, my disappointment was great - after about 2 hours, I could smell nothing anymore; for a compliment that I occasionally receive for good fragrances, Joop Ice unfortunately did not suffice!

I bought Homme Ice three years ago because it smelled very interesting when tested - unfortunately, the bottle is still half full today.

Freshly sprayed, Homme Ice really smells nice, cool, fruity-sweet like plum. A very pleasant scent.

Unfortunately, the top notes fade very quickly - within 5 to 10 minutes - and then the perfume develops a rather synthetic character, in my opinion. This must be due to the tobacco, as sandalwood is actually a very natural, pleasant scent.

That doesn't mean I think Ice is really bad; it just loses its initial scent very quickly and leaves you with a fragrance that you can like, but don't have to (what a stretched sentence, actually...) - for my taste, it's a bit too artificial/synthetic and too sweet.

The sillage of the perfume is quite strong, its longevity rather mediocre, which you can also see in the reviews.

By the way, the bottle is well chosen. Solid, I would say typically Joop!.

review_title: Buttery cinnamon with a candle-like aspect
review_content:
I had to wear it twice to figure it out it wasn't me the problem in detecting the notes in this perfume, but rather the fact that the scent is pretty mild and subtle. I was expecting something strong with bold, uncompromising notes, but instead I got something soft, almost delicate, a fragrance I'd prefer in a candle rather than on my skin.

At the beginning, I get a soft, delicate and powdery cocoa with some floral undertones. It doesn't take long before the cinnamon butter comes up which remains the star during a large portion of the perfume's life. Buttery, almost creamy and lactonic with a warm, spicy cinnamon that accompanies it. The butter note has a waxy (synthetic?) facet I often smell in candles. This might be why I associate this scent to a candle rather than a perfume. After the cinnamon butter starts to wane a bit, I start getting some vanilla orchid and some white sandalwood. It's creamy, gourmand and has a warm, comforting aspect. Caramel further enhances the buttery, thick part of the fragrance. As the base starts to come in, vetiver imparts a mild spiciness while amber adds warmth and bourbon vanilla adds that sweetness we've all come to love and recognize in modern gourmand perfumes.

It's defintely a lovely fragrance, but that buttery, synthetic note that reminds me of candles is the main reason why it won't be making it into my collection. I might also not be a fan of butter and lactonic fragrances on my skin. I'm still pretty happy I got to try it out and I do have to say it stands out from gourmands I've smelled recently.

A white seagull in the royal blue sky. Almost half a century under its belt.
Its flight began in 1974 at Shulton Inc. on the East Coast of the USA. However, turbulent air currents were to land the magnificent wings of the bird at the end of a risky flight path near Birmingham in England in 2020, allowing it to find a new nest in the hangar of Three Pears Ltd.

Dear Hapax, stow your carry-on luggage properly in the overhead compartment, sit up straight, and buckle up, because we will soon be taking off for Seattle.
And thanks in advance for the reminder of this classic!
See you later.

Before every flight, the captain goes through several parameters with his crew. And it should be no different with this fragrance.
Components, historical context, fun factor.

TVC15, the perfume of the first hour and builder of supporting walls in the forum, experienced this seagull similarly and commented super humorously. If interested, check here Blue Stratos EAU DE TOILETTE. I would now like to take over the onward flight.
For in-flight entertainment, I’ll borrow a few musical highlights from the time I experienced as a child.

So, after we have received clearance for takeoff…

Oki, let’s turn on the classic “Love’s Theme” by The Love Unlimited Orchestra…

Swoosh!

Boy, it’s getting foggy here. Somehow, the scent pyramid doesn’t make sense, as the musk in the base immediately causes limited visibility, along with a sweet vanilla note. The listed hesperides are dutifully masked but can still be detected.
Well, dear TVC15, I can only agree with you, tastes are different across the Atlantic. Freshness is associated with musk and vanilla, while hesperides tend to end up in dish soap.

Well, a little anecdote from my side. I once got to bathe with Mr. Bubble, that iconic bubble bath with an extremely funny fruity floral scent. A friendly bubble monster smiled amicably from the label of the pink bottle.
Completely different from the Badedas here at home, full of cozy fir and sober bottle design.
So different, kids got to splash around with the squeaky duck.

And what applied to the little ones should be no exception for adults.
While a deep green Bogart EAU DE TOILETTE cleared its way through dense forests in Europe, the white seagull floated above vanilla musk clouds.

But wait, the fragrance has even more to offer!
This heart is marked by a gentle Love&Peace caress, a classic rose-patchouli.
The earthy grass also comes off slightly sweet. No wonder, it has found a best friend in amber.

Only the lavender remains somewhat steadfast, painting the whole thing herbally fresh and giving the fragrance its characteristic hue. Well, the cedar also provides the necessary support so as not to completely disappear in the fog of love.

Strangely enough, there’s a sprinkling of vanilla powder. Quite a dry ingredient and always on the edge of being bearable. The remaining hesperides are bound with the yellow stuff, hence the freshness of the New World.

Nicely lasting and with a subtle sillage, the juice of the beautiful bottle requires repeated spraying.
The bottle is more than successful, simple and perfectly rounded, plus this beautiful blue color!

So, onward in the 747 to the West Coast. The vastness of the Midwest lies behind us, and Air Traffic Control is directing us over Utah.
Let’s leave the entertainment music to the crew, as I have the impression that it’s quite affectionate in the cabin.
“Baby come back” by Player should get the beautiful Halston uniforms for Braniff International moving a bit.

Ah, we glide without turbulence at 10,000 meters, everything so smooth and almost too flattering.

But what would the 1970s be without incidents during the flight…

Bang!

Pressure drop!

The small hairline crack in the cockpit window became noticeably larger and finally caused the pane to shatter!

All hell breaks loose in the cabin, the co-pilot and flight engineer are hit by flying debris and incapacitated.
The pilot is injured, can hardly see, and had to quickly bring the plane down to a height where one can breathe.
Gasping, he switches on the autopilot.

And the Rocky Mountains are getting closer…

The crew is desperately searching for a suitable substitute pilot among the passengers.

Hey Hapax, your chance!

Don’t worry, in the 1970s, at least in the movies, you could always manage, such quick learning by doing.

Off to the cockpit with you!

Easy, my boy, your fragrance will support you.
You will be prepared step by step for landing by Air Traffic Control via headset. It goes without saying that their instructions can be understood and executed by everyone immediately.

Tss, the passengers again. Typical hysteria. Urgent appointments marked in red on the calendar, special offers at Nordstrom and Sears, the crucial game between the Pittsburgh Steelers and the Seattle Seahawks.
But this rose-patch allows you to stay completely relaxed, excitement is for others.

So, quickly correct the altitude, you’ll handle the crosswinds with ease.
Oops, almost missed the angle, lucky you!

Well, doesn’t the musk vanilla your masterly calm?

Come on, where’s your pilot smile?
Up, up, the Ray Ban gives you the final heroic touch with the randomly available flight jacket!
For what Jonathan the seagull can do is child’s play for you.

Dreamy view, these mighty mountains and in between Salt Lake City with the somewhat hidden airport.

Ah, the runway in sight!
The lavender should now allow you clear visibility, gently now, my boy.
But who am I telling, you remain steadfast like the cedar!

Calculating the descent rate, downdrafts, weight of the aircraft, fuel load, speed, length of the runway, I beg you, one could dismiss that with the fragrance as a second-grade math problem.

“Runway clear, land at your discretion!”

Calm down, Hapax, you’ll manage the last meters. Don’t let the somewhat exaggerated horrified look of the purser with a twisted hand on his forehead and the repeated calling of the creator’s name along with interjections - in high C - from the chief stewardess disturb your calm.

Imagine the asphalt straight as a soft musk trampoline.

Oops, a bit bumpy on the touchdown, don’t forget the thrust reversers!

Well, well, well, where’s the braking power?
The end of the runway is getting closer!

If it weren’t for that vanilla powder, like foam on the runway.

And exactly three centimeters before catastrophe, you brought the plane to a stop!

Come on, now your line.
“I knew we could make it!”

But your personal hell ride is just beginning, because before the hysterically overjoyed crowd dares to make the saving jump over the emergency slides, they will personally thank you.
Each one hugs you, kisses your cheeks sore, and considers you their personal guardian angel.

Okay, you’ve earned the much-needed cruise on the Love Boat towards Fantasy Island.

But that’s another story…

product_name: L'Eau par Kenzo Mirror Edition pour Femme
review_content:
good smell of fresh green, grassy and forest. an intense but fresh green smell, not dark, which to give an idea we could say that at times, but only vaguely, could also remind of a forest near the ocean (but there are no marine or salty notes).

buon odore di verde fresco, erbaceo e di foresta. un odore verde intenso ma fresco, non dark, che per rendere l'idea potremmo dire che a tratti, ma solo vagamente, potrebbe ricordare anche una foresta vicino all'oceano(ma non ci sono note marine o salate)

product_name: L'Eau par Kenzo Mirror Edition pour Femme
review_content:
In Forest Riot, my childhood in the Black Forest meets my favorite vacations in the Scandinavian winter. The scent is exactly what it says on the label: forest. A bit less riot than expected, actually more like softly whispering conifers with a breezy, rustling opening.
Whenever I wear it, my partner always grins around the corner and shouts "Riotttt!"

Unfortunately, the loud green part only lasts a short while. After that, you get a very photorealistic needle-like skin scent that lasts about two hours. In wool clothing, it is absolutely stunningly beautiful.

I wear it whenever I want to escape the rainy life in Hamburg. And I interpret all the coniferous forests of the world into it.

And I think Forest Riot deserves a review. Because even though it is very fleeting, I find that for €40, it's okay for the (very pretty!) bottle, as it is the only forest scent that captures that very special blend of ethereal perfection and rough nature without any additional scratchy incense.

Plea concluded. I love it very much and the new bottle is already ordered.

The fragrance opens with a burst of red apples, but I can also detect some sweet cherry-blossoms, very Japanse, so to speak - and very sweet and verrrry tender. When you think, "Wow, what a lovely start - how is this gonna go on?" you are soon breathing in the aroma of steamed thai-rice (not basmati-rice!) and after a couple of minutes, you are already led to the base which is not as soft as you might have expected. On the contrary, the base is harsh and I seem to detect some unpleasant screechy note in it. Thus this scent has a wonderful start, but a disappointing ending - and after 30 min you wonder where it's all gone - you are left with nearly nothing at all, just a faint whisper of some woody base commonly used in male fragrances.
I like my rice-dishes much spicier and more substantial. This "Dolce Riso" is not even suitable as a dessert,it's a cute little appetizer which leaves you with an empty stomach.

I love the rice/vanilla scent of K. Amour but am not always in the mood for its hairspray overtones. While K. Amour is fixing her hair for a big date, though, her cousin Dolce Riso (Sweet Rice) is in the kitchen. DR is going to impress her date with a cool jasmine rice pudding, laced with diced Granny Smith apples, a dusting of vanilla powder, a squeeze of lime, and a shotglass of absinthe on the side. While DR is approachable, she's not quite cuddly. Rather, her unusual combination of scents make her exotic and sophisticated. KA is going to an outdoor cafe with her date. DR is going to an avant-garde play with hers. Both are well worth your time.

I am not a fan of gourmand scents. What smells like food belongs on my plate! And that’s exactly the case with Dolce Riso.
Sweet rice pudding with grated apple, refined with a hint of lemon and vanilla powdered sugar... and I rummage through the cupboard for diapers and a onesie. One should be appropriately dressed at the table.

The actor Karl Farkas once said to Zarah Leander when he saw her eye-catching and revealing dress:
"A hungry infant would go insane at this sight"
I think, had she also worn Dolce Riso, there would have been no stopping for a hungry infant. He would have jumped at her décolletage like Chucky the killer doll ;-)

Dolce Riso will make gourmand lovers happy who forgo Angel&Co. in favor of their fellow humans during the summer. Despite its sweetness and powderiness, Dolce Riso is unobtrusive and light, and can easily be worn on hot days.

EDIT: I thank Turandot for the little snack! ;-)

The scent is neither masculine, nor feminine, nor unisex.
This is a children's fragrance, no, this is a baby fragrance. And this baby is definitely innocent.

This is how little diaper-wearers smell AFTER! being pampered, with plenty of powder on their bottoms, after they have devoured their whole grain apple puree! from Claus Hipp, without spitting and without crying. I mean the babies of the kind that do nothing but sleep, grow, and smell good.

I’ve been told that I was also such a wonderful, sweet child. Until I was seven years old, I didn’t say a word.
One day, I didn’t like my soup and I said “Mama! The soup is totally over-salted!”
“Wow! Child, you speak!?! Why have you never said anything before???”
“Why should I, everything was fine until now.”

Thank you Louce for your verbal inspiration for this fantastic blind buy!

Freshly soaked, white rice. Best when it’s called “fragrant rice.” This rich, substantial, carbohydrate-sweet scent with a pinch of salt that can have such immense clarity and fullness at the same time. Do you know it? I love it. When it comes to eating, I only like rice with flavor, so not plain (e.g., such a delicious Risotto Milanese with lots of saffron, cheese, and bone marrow or an Arabic rice with dates, spices, and nuts, or, or, or...),... but for smelling, I like it plain and white.
However, I was indeed skeptical about a fragrance called “Dolce Riso”... the “Dolce” made me suspect that it would be a version of milk rice scent (preferably with cinnamon sugar). I mentally heard the colorful little hunger shouting “done!” before I even sniffed it and was prepared for anything.
But no... Dolce Riso truly has that rice note that I love! Fantastic! And as a perfume... not the delicate kitchen scent from the pot, but a delicious, sense-activating scent on the skin.
Apicius writes that he can’t really imagine anything under the grain and rice note. Hmmm... I feel quite differently: I find it distinctly recognizable. Apicius... if you still have a milliliter of Dolce Riso, please inhale it deeply over your next cooked white rice for my (and/or Tivellon’s) sake and then compare it with the scent. We do agree very much on the “minimal apple.”
Just like Fran, this super charming lime captivates me at the beginning. I don’t smell the powderiness that strongly. The spices then lead the wonderful rice scent to vanilla, and there the supporting element develops (by the way, incredibly long-lasting for me). The vanilla bed gently and soothingly envelops the non-milky rice, allowing it to spread out and relax for a long time.

In doing so, Dolce Riso doesn’t become completely unsexy, as gourmand fragrances often do... OK, it’s not the boiling lava ecstasy scent... but at least it remains always appealing and tickles sensual associations of not just cozy physicality and warmth.

The name of this perfume piques curiosity. Is it really a gourmand fragrance? Well, the wheel hasn't exactly been reinvented here. Shortly after spraying, I recognize - this is the scent Minotaure by Paloma Picasso, just slightly altered. Clearly a vanilla scent, somewhat sandy-dry, yet still voluminous, with citrusy top notes. But vanilla alone doesn't capture it; this...

I'm not sure if all scents that remind one of sweet desserts can be classified as gourmand. I haven't done so. Here, I somehow miss the oriental opulence of dessert. No honey, no cardamom, no cinnamon, no caramel. So not gourmand, rather gourmandchenlein, kids there is dessert!!!

Sunday dinner at grandma's or mom's, who has once again outdone herself with a homemade lemon cream.
That's my first impression: a beautiful, pastel yellow citrus cream, slightly sweet, but with a little twist of sour. Absolutely delicious!
I don't notice the rice in the slightest, not even in the slightest hint. And if there is an apple, it's a very green one, flirting with the lemon.

In the middle, a grain porridge flows, made of oats, a bit of barley flakes, maybe there are some rice flakes in there that I don't notice. Again, the fresh fruit is mixed in.
The rest is pudding. Yes, vanilla pudding, homemade, with a secret. It's not just sweet, it's an old family recipe where you don't quite know what all is mixed in.
I must add here that I HATE pudding! But Dolce Riso at least reconciles me with the scent.

This is already delicious, but at the moment it has a bit of a hard time against the formidable Bel Ami on the other arm, but why am I testing two such different scents simultaneously anyway.

A perfume that completely does without flowers. A delicate and buoyant gourmand scent, but very light and uncomplicated. Plus, this extraordinary sweet grain note. I like Dolce Riso.

The lime at the beginning comes through very clearly for me and does not disappear immediately. It takes away the apple-like quality from the apple. Therefore, Dolce Riso is not an apple scent for me. It is rather delicately fruity sweet and very lightly spicy. The pepper and the mugwort create a nice contrast to the more citrusy fruits in the opening.

What makes it so special for me is this delicious powderiness that instantly comes out of the bottle after spraying. Not dusty dry or cloying, but fluffy and lovely, as if a yellow-pastel powder cloud is always hovering a few millimeters above the skin. A successful combination of musk, tonka bean, and the rice note, I assume.

The vanilla in the base does not become very sweet for me. The scent develops rather in a very delicate bitter-herb direction. The pepper note lingers for a long time and ensures that Dolce Riso does not end in a boring vanilla sweetness, but remains deliciously dry.

The longevity could be better, but the scent is truly special; I know nothing comparable.

review_title: Economic Miracle Dessert and Soul Food Scent for Sweet Tooth Lovers
review_content:
Let’s continue with the experimental series Calé, and here is another hit. For me and my nose, for my sentimentality, my childhood memories. Those that gain in value with the passing decades, and possibly also in idealization. So be it.

Dolce Riso - the sweet rice.
I confess here that I am a dyed-in-the-wool rice pudding fanatic. Soul food extraordinaire is lukewarm or cold rice pudding, for me THE comfort food.
And if it should be particularly good: Reis Trautmannsdorf. One of the trendy desserts of the 50s and 60s, when Toast Hawaii was also top class among warm snacks.

It is a vanilla rice pudding, into which whipped cream is folded with a bit of gelatin.
It is flavored with maraschino. There is thickened sour cherry compote with port wine in it, or again maraschino. Oh my goodness, I feel a twitching desire to RUN into the kitchen and start cooking - but I have neither maraschino nor cherries on hand.

This sweet craving is also triggered by “Dolce Riso” - without the cooking compulsion.
Finest sweet, fruity-creamy, and mildly juicy scents open up. For me, it’s an immediate feel-good moment, a scent I would love to spray on myself right after a bath or shower.
Even though the same components nominally form the top note here as in “Assolo,” there is a juiciness and creaminess that thankfully differs significantly from Assolo.

Grains and rice emerge in the middle phase, the tastiest rice pudding, still lukewarm, vanilla-scented, lightly sweetened. Powdery, but not dusty. Sweet, but not “squeaky.”
Tonka bean and vanilla make their presence known, but are still overshadowed by the grain notes. Fresh white bread, little rolls, and the school breakfast standard of early years: porridge, nicely cooked, and then poured over with cold milk. Or quite lavishly: with liquid cream.
This is how Dolce Riso smells - gentle, familiar, nourishing. Comforting, mild, and enveloping. Close to the skin with a tiny sillage that hardly stands out (Who smells like rice pudding?) Not a baby scent, not a powder scent, but a fine, subtle skin caresser in the tradition of “Sensi,” perhaps. By the end of the day, a delicate scent remains on the skin, announcing vanilla, the listed musk is not the seducer, but the storyteller of soothing tales.
Another one for my list, I want to own it to occasionally indulge in a calorie-free Reis Trautmannsdorf or to add a generous splash of “softness” and “cuddling” to my cashmere sweater.

A hint of soft citrus freshness and then - swelling, sweet, heavy… Actually, I don’t like "sweet" - and I mean not at all!
And on me, the rice initially spreads out clearly sweet and full, almost a bit sticky.

But here it doesn’t bother me - on the contrary, I feel warm and for this moment, everything is good. I am satiated. I am satiated! Satisfied. Complete.

This has nothing to do with capricious sweet floral notes. Nothing here lures with anything affirmatively-sensual and secretive until the end. Nothing screams: "Hello, I am here", "look at me", "I want you to want me"… and "finally tell me that I exist!" Here there is no lack from which desire grows. No, here the moment of "being-with-oneself" arises, after which approaching others loses its compulsion - freedom means.

After the carbohydrate-rich sweetness that stops where it usually becomes uncomfortable for me, that becomes dull, warm, and enveloping, then comes the spice. The white pepper that tames the vanilla, the nuttiness of the tonka bean. As if the rice were cooked over an open fire and as if it were enough for the entire village.

After hours (and I mean many hours), the musk lingers very faintly, like the body imprint on the sheet after deep sleep.

… and it is by no means unsexy to be satiated, well-rested, warm.
I like myself with this fragrance.

Well, one shouldn't expect anything, then one won't be disappointed. Although... Okay, let's take it step by step. In Spain, there is a super delicious ice cream called "Leche rizada." I thought of that when I saw the name Dolce Riso. Leche rizada has a creamy flavor of rice pudding with cinnamon and is suuuper tasty. However, Dolce Riso has nothing to do with this ice cream;...

Here, the rice and grains intrigued me, and I imagined a powdery-milky scent.

Unfortunately, none of that is detectable.

It's more of a woody fragrance with a harsh, aftershave-like undertone. Powdery notes are present, but they don't save the scent. I think the mugwort could have been left out. It likely contributes to this harsh note, which unfortunately lingers in the later scent aura and wafts around your nose.

For me, it's not a pleasant fragrance, but a disappointment.
I can better imagine it on men.

Grate the apple, squeeze the lime, finely crush a little mugwort in a mortar, mix together and set aside. Cook rice pudding, take the wheat that was ground and soaked the night before out of the fridge and stir it in with the rice. Add the apple-lime-mugwort mixture. Scrape out the vanilla pod, finely grind half a tonka bean and add both. As an alternative, leave out the...

...the perception of fragrance is.
I once bought a sample of the scent blind.
For me, this fragrance has neither anything sweet nor any "delicious" note; it came across as completely woody.
That's why I gave the sample away.

Today, 4 samples from Mr. W. arrived, and the 1st test was this little treat. On paper - unremarkable... So I generously applied it on my skin and went out among people, which was already quite bold.

I hoped to catch the desired rice pudding note (I loooove rice pudding!), but: nothing. Instead, I found something heavy, floral (?), that barely brushed against the headache threshold. Was that all there was? Right after that, the lime sneaked in and kept the "flowers" wonderfully in check. I literally breathed a sigh of relief!

So, a citrus scent? No, it changed completely again. I somehow missed the heart note, but what remained was a cotton-soft, delicate-powdery, slightly sweet vanilla cloud that completely enveloped me and - in contrast to my loud "Vanitas" - remained very subtle.

I couldn't detect apple, mugwort, or pepper in this 1st test, nor do I explicitly perceive rice and grains. Overall, a lovely feel-good scent.

Edit 1: After the 2nd test, my enthusiasm has waned a bit - I now have the "counterpart," namely Lann-Ael on the other arm, and in direct comparison, Lann-Ael IS AMAZING! Pure vanilla crescent, simply sweet, powdery, soft - in comparison, Dolce Riso unfortunately falls short for me in fascination. But I will continue to test!

Edit 2: In the meantime, I have tested the scent extensively: And now only the lime is making an appearance, I hardly perceive all the other components anymore, certainly not in a differentiated way. I definitely won't be buying this one.

I used to think that the brand Clean made insipid and bland soapy fragrances, but since giving them a fair go, I have come to understand the beauty of a crisp and clean scent for everyday wear.

Heavy hitting fragrances can become tiring after awhile, and that's when a scent such as this one is highly appreciated. Clean Ultimate has unisex tendencies, with the dominant lavender accord giving this composition a slightly masculine edge.

Lavender has many soothing properties, so it's easy to feel comforted by wearing Clean Ultimate. It's casual, clean and smooth. I find it inoffensive and versatile enough to be worn all year long.

Some may complain about the linear composition, but for something so soapy and delicate, I don't know why you'd want it any other way. I personally believe that the simplicity works a treat.

I do happen to adore the scent of lavender and musk, so Clean Ultimate suits me to a tee. The only disappointing factor, was its lack of lasting strength. It lasted a meagre two hours on my skin.

I'm giving it the thumbs up despite the longevity issue, and I whole-heartedly recommend it, especially if you enjoy the somewhat unique Clean Warm Cotton as well.

Opinions can certainly differ - I have never received as many compliments for a fragrance as I have for this one. And after being able to try it again after years, I remember why.

Delicate, ethereal, and infinitely feminine, Ultimate truly lives up to its name. For me, the focus of this fragrance is clearly on the lily of the valley, but a very gentle, fragile lily of the valley that is carefully embraced by rose and jasmine. The citrus notes are only subtly perceptible; however, throughout the entire fragrance journey, a wonderfully sweet musk resonates, which never makes the scent powdery and does not take away from its lightness.

Ultimate is in a way simple, but by no means simplistic, if you understand what I mean. Instead, it is a harmonious, wonderfully balanced fragrance composition that is both refreshing and grounding, providing both lightness and protection. A truly wonderful summer scent, albeit with limited longevity and sillage.

P.S. It is stated here that Ultimate is a unisex fragrance... um, yes, if a man likes to dance through the flower garden in a dress, that might be accurate :))

Here I expected something completely different, namely a "fresh laundry scent," but this Clean is not a laundry detergent scent but a fresh floral scent. Light and floral at the beginning. Clearly a rose scent with musk; I can't perceive the other fragrance notes. It doesn't last very long and unfortunately becomes quite sharp on the skin; somehow the fragrance notes don't quite harmonize with each other for me.
Also here: due to the many roses, more of a women's fragrance.

Ultimate by Clean is a very good alternative to the unfortunately discontinued scent Helmut Lang Eau de Cologne. Fresh, powdery, and unique. Unfortunately, the Clean fragrance does not last as long as the scent by Helmut Lang.

product_name: L'Eau par Kenzo Love L'Eau pour Homme
review_content:
White Hinoki is a truly successful fragrance that is excellent for everyday wear. The opening is fresh and citrusy, making it immediately pleasant to wear, even on warmer days or in the office. After about 2-3 hours, a sweet-woody note unfolds, which gains a special depth from a subtle whiskey accent.

I specifically searched for a fragrance that captures the sweet-smoky wood character of the Japanese cypress. This fascinated me back in Kyoto, and White Hinoki comes very close to that in the base note. Of course, it’s not a 1:1 match with the scent I experienced there - especially due to the fresh start - but that’s exactly what makes it more suitable for daily wear, as it never becomes too heavy or too sweet.

The longevity is impressive: the fragrance easily lasts 10 hours on the skin and develops beautifully over time. The projection is moderate at first and becomes more subtle later, making it versatile for use, whether for work, leisure, or a relaxed evening.

The bottle is also worth mentioning. The simple, white design looks modern and elegant. Additionally, it feels pleasantly heavy in the hand due to its weight and high-quality craftsmanship - a detail that further emphasizes the value of the perfume.

Overall, it’s a not overly complex fragrance with strong performance at a fair price. The individual notes are all easily perceivable. For some, the fresh accent at the beginning may seem off-putting. However, the woody note comes through with time and then dominates. Especially if you’re looking for an authentic Hinoki vibe, you should definitely try White Hinoki. Clear recommendation!

~ Inspiration ~
I haven't heard or seen anything about this Lancome perfume until now...

~ Bottle ~
What stands out is the exceptionally curved shape. The gradient from a warm orange to a cool blue evokes summery associations. The name "Calypso" reminds me of a popsicle (Calippo), further enhancing the summer feeling.

~ Scent ~
Sour bergamot flashes briefly upon spraying, but then gives way to ripe, sweet pears, plums, and a bit of pepper that tingles lightly in the nose. After a short time, floral accords in the form of roses, lily of the valley, jasmine, and slightly more robust freesias join in, preventing the scent from becoming too sweet. Delicious raspberries and vanilla form the base note with a hint of patchouli.

~ Longevity ~
On my skin, it lasts about 4-5 hours (a bit longer on hair and clothing).

~ Occasion ~
A pleasant spring and summer perfume for the warmer days of the year.

~ Conclusion ~
I wouldn't have thought this perfume was from Lancome. It's very fruity (pears) and floral (roses), which I don't typically associate with this brand - but I like it :)

It’s possible!
After recently having constant involuntary encounters with pears while testing fragrances from Marc Jacobs, I was on the lookout for a Williams Christ pear scent that I would finally like. And voila - here it is.
Calypso has slipped by me unnoticed until now; apparently, it is no longer available in stores, so it was a great coincidence that I came across a sample of it. (What the name Lollipop is all about, however, escapes me, especially since I thought the divine Miss Carey had claimed that name for herself...)
Calypso starts with a fresh-fruity (who would have thought?) note, with pepper adding the necessary kick.
The heart note is fantastically deliciously pear-like, and not too sweet. Also not too artificial. More freesia-pear-like. But still primarily pear. I unfortunately don’t know where the plum and all the supposed flowers are hanging out, but I don’t really care.
The base is quite nice and wearable with a hint of patchouli and barely noticeable vanilla, even if it doesn’t quite fit the pear impression overall, like with Liberté by Cacharel, where the base also doesn’t fit, otherwise I would like it better.
Overall, a lovely summer scent, not too far from Escadas, but more refined and less sweet.

Calypso is a rather unremarkable fruity, fresh perfume. I bought it a few years ago but could never really warm up to it. It was very peach/pear heavy. The other notes remained subtle in the background. I ultimately sold it again.

Notes: Taiwan incense cedar (Calocedrus formosana), patchouli, chocolate, rum, tonka bean, baked nuts, amber, ambroxan, labdanum
Review: A cacao-themed fragrance. Sweetness of baked nuts and cacao with tonka beans, mixed with the natural incensy note from Taiwan incense cedar, gives a clear vibe of the mysterious Aztec culture. A special gourmand and incense combination reminded me of the day of the dead with fun and food.

Proraso Green is a very nice eucalyptus & menthol aftershave. The menthol isn't overly strong such that it provides a mild sting when applied after wet shaving. Quite refreshing. Everything a guy could want in an old school aftershave.

Bottle has a splash opening under the cap; no sprayer. Longevity is quite fleeting. It's gone after an hour at most allowing you to apply a different fragrance that will last longer. Projection is also soft after the first 5 or 10 minutes. Perfect aftershave for any time of the year. One of my favorites.

Being the only splash I've used, Lozione Dopobarba (green) is the standard for me. It's a classic masculine eucalyptus and menthol mix, with an appropriate amount of after-burn to give that old school sensation of "feeling alive".

This splash will accompany you with only a short performance, which I personally appreciate. I apply it for myself. Plus, I love perfumes, so I wouldn't want my aftershave to take the spotlight. Splashes, in my amateur opinion, make sense to last no more than an hour and should more or less fade by the time I arrive to my destination, if I am to go out after applying.

One 100ml bottle lasts, on average, 18 months for me. So the value is top-notch. After the morning rituals with Proraso shaving soap or Taylor of Old Bond St. shaving cream, as cliché as it sounds, I really feel at my best slapping some of this classic juice on the face and neck.

A little more than just eucalyptus and menthol is probably in Proraso "Linea Verde" - but it’s really a shame that it evaporates so quickly. The scent lasts hardly longer than the cooling effect of the menthol. However, the healing ice breath of the menthol is indeed the strength of this aftershave. It soothes irritated skin, almost numbing it like an ice spray for sports injuries. It works, it alleviates, it cares for and refreshes - and it doesn’t sting at all, even when you spray the aftershave directly into the opened pores with the atomizer of the large 500ml bottle.

I occasionally consider adding some classic aftershave from men’s grooming to my fragrance arsenal - a Floïd or a Pitralon or one of the many Bay Rum-laurel variants. And then I end up not doing it: Proraso LV simply works too well, by the way, regardless of the season. And since I only shave every three days, the 500ml bottle with the atomizer has now lasted into its fourth year; however, this year a replacement is due.

Certainly beyond the Alps, one of the best-selling aftershaves and there is a reason for that, I know only a few aftershaves that leave a similarly good and fresh feeling on the skin! Proraso is a top aftershave and still a secret tip, at least in Germany and Austria! I would describe the scent as aquatic with a hint of eucalyptus, surely there are finer waters out there but the skin feel after shaving with this product is top!

One expects not only a fragrance from an aftershave but also skin care. This little water does indeed provide some good care and has certainly earned many fans because of this property.

It also smells good. Endless eucalyptus, menthol, which you can feel through its cooling effect. The latter is even so intense that I wash my hands after using it to prevent accidentally touching my eyes.

Now for the big downside: After just about an hour, the scent is gone. And other aftershaves can definitely do better.

I have dark, thick facial hair. The dream of all beard wearers. The only problem is, I don’t wear a beard. Aside from a goatee during my teenage years, it was never my thing. If I didn’t shave in the morning, by noon I would have a three-day stubble, and by the next morning, my razor would be put to the test. That’s why I’ve had 365 shaving days a year for over 20...

Always a pleasure. Even after years, I enjoy my wet shave
again and again. The entire green line was, is, and will remain wonderful.
Forget the overpriced, snobbish brands (I'm talking about RS & RC now) buy yourself the tube for little money and this lovely, cheap, simple splash. You can really feel how it works on the skin. Since the scent fades after about 1 hour, wearing EDT is no problem. So guys, that's it
